column3: Germans use 10.000
column5: French use 10 000
column6: 50 etc.

column1: My first approach would be: Take the string
column2: parse it backwards
column3: until I encounter a separator and use this as my decimal separator. The obvious flaw with that: 10.000 would be interpreted as 10.

column1: Another approach: if the string contains 2 different non-numeric characters
column2: use the last one as the decimal separator and discard the others. If I only have one
column3: check if it occurs more than once and discard it if it does. It it only appears once
column4: check if it has 3 digits after it. If yes
column5: discard it
column6: otherwise use it as decimal separator.

column1: The obvious "best solution" would be to detect the User's culture or Browser
column2: but that does not work if you have a Frenchman an an en-US Windows/Browser.

column1: 833##C##1171##C##0.62034174753353##C##2766.10855234973##C##0##C##1440##C##0##C##8384##C##Editing database records by multiple users##C##I have designed database tables (normalised
column2: on an MS SQL server) and created a standalone windows front end for an application that will be used by a handful of users to add and edit information. We will add a web interface to allow searching accross our production area at a later date.

column1: I am concerned that if two users start editing the same record then the last to commit the update would be the 'winner' and important information may be lost. A number of solutions come to mind but I'm not sure if I am going to create a bigger headache.
1. Do nothing and hope that two users are never going to be editing the same record at the same time. *- Might never happed but what if it does?*

2. Editing routine could store a copy of the original data as well as the updates and then compare when the user has finished editing. If they differ show user and comfirm update *- Would require two copies of data to be stored.*
3. Add last updated DATETIME column and check it matches when we update
column2: if not then show differences. *- requires new column in each of the relevant tables.*

column1: 4. Create an editing table that registers when users start editing a record that will be checked and prevent other users from editing same record. *- would require carful thought of program flow to prevent deadlocks and records becoming locked if a user crashes out of the program.*
Are there any better solutions or should I go for one of these?##C##<mssql><database><databases>##C##@$R$@

column1: 1069##C##5108##C##3.22936102747917e-06##C##2765.68748002313##C##1##C##2581##C##0##C##31225##C##Heap corruption under Win32; how to locate?##C##I'm working on a **multithreaded** C++ application that is corrupting the heap.  The usual tools to locate this corruption seem to be inapplicable.  Old builds (18 months old) of the source code exhibit the same behaviour as the most recent release
column2: so this has been around for a long time and just wasn't noticed; on the downside
column3: source deltas can't be used to identify

column1: The prompt for crashing behaviuor is to generate throughput in this system - socket transfer of data which is munged into an internal representation.  I have a set of test data that will periodically cause the app to exception (various places
column2: various causes - including heap alloc failing
column3: thus: heap corruption).

column1: The behaviour seems related to CPU power or memory bandwidth; the more of each the machine has
column2: the easier it is to crash.  Disabling a hyper-threading core or a dual-core core reduces the rate of (but does not eliminate) corruption.  This suggests a timing related issue.

column1: When it's run under a lightweight debug environment (say Visual Studio 98 / AKA MSVC6) the heap corruption is reasonably easy to reproduce - ten or fifteen minutes pass before something fails horrendously and exceptions
column2: like an alloc; when running under a sophisticated debug environment (Rational Purify
column3: VS2008/MSVC9 or even Microsoft Application Verifier) the system becomes memory-speed bound and doesn't crash (Memory-bound: CPU is not getting above 50%
column4: disk light is not on
column5: the program's going as fast it can
column6: box consuming 1.3G of 2G of RAM).  So
column7: **I've got a choice between being able to reproduce the problem (but not identify the cause) or being able to idenify the cause or a problem I can't reproduce.**

column1: My current best guesses as to where to next is:

1. Get an insanely grunty box (to replace the current dev box: 2Gb RAM in an E6550 Core2 Duo); this will make it possible to repro the crash causing mis-behaviour when running under a powerful debug environment; or

2. Rewrite operators new and delete to use VirtualAlloc and VirtualProtect to mark memory as read-only as soon as it's done with.  Run under MSVC6 and have the OS catch the bad-guy who's writing to freed memory.  Yes
column2: this is a sign of desperation: who the hell rewrites new and delete?!  I wonder if this is going to make it as slow as under Purify et al.
no: Shipping with Purify instrumentation built in is not an option.

column1: A collegue just walked past and asked "Stack Overflow?  Are we getting stack overflows now?!?"

column2: the question: **How do I locate the heap corruptor?**##C##<c++><debugging><heap><windows><purify><multithreaded>##C##@$R$@

Is there a way one can ensure that the exceptions thrown are always caught using try/catch by the calling function?

When data is stored on disk based storage devices
column2: it is stored as blocks of data. These blocks are accessed in their entirety
column3: making them the atomic disk access operation. Disk blocks are structured in much the same way as linked lists; both contain a section for data
column4: a pointer to the location of the next node (or block)
column5: and both need not be stored contiguously.

column1: Due to the fact that a number of records can only be sorted on one field
column2: we can state that searching on a field that isnt sorted requires a Linear Search which requires N/2 block accesses
column3: where N is the number of blocks that the table spans. If that field is a non-key field (i.e. doesnt contain unique entries) then the entire table space must be searched at N block accesses.

column2: a Binary Search may be used
column3: this has log2 N block accesses. Also since the data is sorted given a non-key field
column4: the rest of the table doesnt need to be searched for duplicate values
column5: once a higher value is found. Thus the performance increase is substantial.

column1: Indexing is a way of sorting a number of records on multiple fields. Creating an index on a field in a table creates another data structure which holds the field value
column2: and pointer to the record it relates to. This index structure is then sorted
column3: allowing Binary Searches to be performed on it.

column1: The downside to indexing is that these indexes require additional space on the disk
column2: since the indexes are stored together in a MyISAM database
column3: this file can quickly reach the size limits of the underlying file system if many fields within the same table are indexed.

column2: lets outline a sample database table schema;

column1: Field name Data type Size on disk
Note: char was used in place of varchar to allow for an accurate size on disk value.
This sample database contains five million rows
column2: and is unindexed. The performance of several queries will now be analyzed. These are a query using the id (a sorted key field) and one using the firstName (a non-key unsorted field).

column1: Given our sample database of r = 5
column3: 000 records of a fixed size giving a record length of R = 204 bytes and they are stored in a MyISAM database which is using the default block size B = 1
column4: 024 bytes. The blocking factor of the table would be bfr = (B/R) = 1024/204 = 5 records per disk block. The total number of blocks required to hold the table is N = (r/bfr) = 5000000/5 = 1
column6: 000 blocks.

column1: A linear search on the id field would require an average of N/2 = 500
column2: 000 block accesses to find a value given that the id field is a key field. But since the id field is also sorted a binary search can be conducted requiring an average of log2 1000000 = 19.93 = 20 block accesses. Instantly we can see this is a drastic improvement.

column1: Now the firstName field is neither sorted
column2: so a binary search is impossible
column3: nor are the values unique
column4: and thus the table will require searching to the end for an exact N = 1
column6: 000 block accesses. It is this situation that indexing aims to correct.

column1: Given that an index record contains only the indexed field and a pointer to the original record
column2: it stands to reason that it will be smaller than the multi-field record that it points to. So the index itself requires fewer disk blocks that the original table
column3: which therefore requires fewer block accesses to iterate through. The schema for an index on the firstName field is outlined below;

column1: Field name Data type Size on disk

column3: 4 or 5 bytes in length depending on the size of the table.

column1: Given our sample database of r = 5
column3: 000 records with an index record length of R = 54 bytes and using the default block size B = 1
column4: 024 bytes. The blocking factor of the index would be bfr = (B/R) = 1024/54 = 18 records per disk block. The total number of blocks required to hold the table is N = (r/bfr) = 5000000/18 = 277
column5: 778 blocks.

column1: Now a search using the firstName field can utilise the index to increase performance. This allows for a binary search of the index with an average of log2 277778 = 18.08 = 19 block accesses. To find the address of the actual record
column2: which requires a further block access to read
column3: bringing the total to 19 + 1 = 20 block accesses
column4: a far cry from the 1
column6: 000 block accesses required by the non-indexed table.

column1: Given that creating an index requires additional disk space (277
column2: 778 blocks extra from the above example)
column3: and that too many indexes can cause issues arising from the file systems size limits
column4: careful thought must be used to select the correct fields to index.

column1: Since indexes are only used to speed up the searching for a matching field within the records
column2: it stands to reason that indexing fields used only for output would be simply a waste of disk space and processing time when doing an insert or delete operation
column3: and thus should be avoided. Also given the nature of a binary search
column4: the cardinality or uniqueness of the data is important. Indexing on a field with a cardinality of 2 would split the data in half
column5: whereas a cardinality of 1
column6: 000 would return approximately 1
column7: 000 records. With such a low cardinality the effectiveness is reduced to a linear sort
column8: and the query optimizer will avoid using the index if the cardinality is greater than 30% of the record number
column9: effectively making the index a waste of space.##C##<databases><indexing><article>##C##@$R$@

column1: > LEFT JOIN application_UserPermissions emp ON perm.ApplicationID = emp.ApplicationID

1535##C##14067##C##0.0623881136998534##C##2765.19318831014##C##1##C##1891##C##0##C##1564##C##Reducing duplicate error handling code in C#?##C##I've never been completely happy with the way exception handling works
column2: there's a lot exceptions and try/catch brings to the table (stack unwinding
column3: etc.)
column4: but it seems to break a lot of the OO model in the process.

column2: here's the problem:

column1: Let's say you have some class which wraps or includes networked file IO operations (e.g. reading and writing to some file at some particular UNC path somewhere). For various reasons you don't want those IO operations to fail
column2: so if you detect that they fail you retry them and you keep retrying them until they succeed or you reach a timeout. I already have a convenient RetryTimer class which I can instantiate and use to sleep the current thread between retries and determine when the timeout period has elapsed
column3: etc.

column1: The problem is that you have a bunch of IO operations in several methods of this class
column2: and you need to wrap each of them in try-catch / retry logic.

column1: // do some file IO which may succeed or fail

column2: how do you avoid duplicating most of this code for every file IO operation throughout the class? My solution was to use anonymous delegate blocks and a single method in the class which executed the delegate block passed to it. This allowed me to do things like this in other methods:
but it leaves a lot to be desired. I'd like to hear how other people would solve this sort of problem.##C##<c#><exception><error-handling>##C##@$R$@

column1: 1949##C##20311##C##3.68288784706965##C##2764.75376508106##C##0##C##2080##C##2##C##4327##C##How many DataContexts are appropriate?##C##In order to fully use LinqToSql in an ASP.net 3.5 application
column2: it is necessary to create [DataContext][1] [classes][2] (which is usually done using the designer in VS 2008). From the UI perspective
column3: the DataContext is a design of the sections of your database that you would like to expose to through LinqToSql and is integral in setting up the ORM features of LinqToSql.

column1: My question is: I am setting up a project that uses a large database where all tables are interconnected in some way through Foreign Keys. My first inclination is to make one huge DataContext class that models the entire datbase. That way I could in theory (though I don't know if this would be needed in practice) use the Foreign Key connections that are generated through LinqToSql to easily go between related objects in my code
column2: insert related objects
column3: etc.

column2: after giving it some thought
column3: I am now thinking that it may make more sense to create multiple DataContext classes
column4: each one relating to a specific namespace or logical interrelated section within my database. My main concern is that instantiating and disposing one huge DataContext class all the time for individual operations that relate to specific areas of the Database would be impose an unnecessary imposition on application resources. Additionally
column5: it is easier to create and manage smaller DataContext files than one big one. The thing that I would lose is that there would be some distant sections of the database that would not be navigable through LinqToSql (even though a chain of relationships connects them in the actual database). Additionally
column6: there would be some table classes that would exist in more than one DataContext.

column1: Any thoughts or experience on whether multiple DataContexts (corresponding to DB namespaces) are appropriate in place of (or in addition to) one very large DataContext class (corresponding to the whole DB)?

column1: 2328##C##94639##C##3.96035008085892##C##2764.42207500013##C##0##C##1957##C##0##C##2334##C##Tracking state using ASP.NET AJAX / ICallbackEventHandler##C##I have a problem with maintaining state in an ASP.NET AJAX page. Short version: I need some way to update the page ViewState after an async callback has been made
column2: to reflect any state changes the server made during the async call.

column1: This seems to be a common problem
column2: but I will describe my scenario to help explain:

column1: I have a grid-like control which has some JavaScript enhancements - namely
column2: the ability to drag and drop columns and rows. When a column or row is dropped into a new position
column3: an AJAX method is invoked to notify the control server-side and fire a corresponding server-side event ("OnColumnMoved" or "OnRowMoved").

column2: by default
column3: send the entire page as the request. That way the page goes through a complete lifecycle
column4: viewstate is persisted and the state of the control is restored before the RaiseCallbackEvent method is invoked.

column2: since the AJAX call does not update the page
column3: the ViewState reflects the *original* state of the control
column4: even after the column or row has been moved. So the second time a client-side action occurs
column5: the AJAX request goes to the server and the page & control are built back up again to reflect the *first* state of the control
column6: not the state after the first column or row was moved.

column1: This problem extends to many implications. For example if we have a client-side/AJAX action to add a new item to the grid
column2: and then a row is dragged
column3: the grid is built server-side with one less item than on the client-side.

column1: And finally & most seriously for my specific example
column2: the actual data source object we are acting upon is stored in the page ViewState. That was a design decision to allow keeping a stateful copy of the manipulated data which can either be committed to DB after many manipulations or discarded if the user backs out. That is very difficult to change.
again
column3: I need a way for the page ViewState to be updated on callback after the AJAX method is fired.##C##<asp.net><ajax><viewstate>##C##@$R$@

column1: 2970##C##15430##C##4.415878391359##C##2764.0031747683##C##1##C##5375##C##2##C##3219##C##My website got hacked... What should I do?##C##My dad called me today and said people going to his website were getting 168 viruses trying to download to their computers. He isn't technical at all
column2: and built the whole thing with a WYSIWYG editor.

column1: I popped his site open and viewed the source
column2: and there was a line of Javascript includes at the bottom of the source right before the closing HTML tag. They included this file (among many others): http://www.98hs.ru/js.js <-- TURN OFF JAVASCRIPT BEFORE YOU GO TO THAT URL.

column1: So I commented it out for now. It turns out his ftp password was a plain dictionary word six letters long
column2: so we think that's how it got hacked. We've changed his password to an 8+ digit non-word string (he wouldn't go for a passphrase since he is a hunt-n-peck typer).

column1: I did a [whois on 98hs.ru][1] and found it is hosted from a server in Chili. There is actually an e-mail address associated with it too
column2: but I seriously doubt this person is the culprit. Probably just some other site that got hacked...

column1: I have no idea what to do at this point though as I've never dealt with this sort of thing before. Anyone have any suggestions?
He was using plain jane un-secured ftp through webhost4life.com. I don't even see a way to *do* sftp on their site. I'm thinking his username and password got intercepted?

column2: to make this more relevant to the community
column3: what are the steps you should take/best practices you should follow to protect your website from getting hacked?**

column2: here is the line of code that "magically" got added to his file (and isn't in his file on his computer -- I've left it commented out just to make absolute sure it won't do anything on this page
column3: although I'm sure Jeff would guard against this):

column1: 3260##C##1171##C##3.16175096062943##C##2763.56714313664##C##0##C##944##C##1##C##41015##C##Peak detection of measured signal##C##We use a data acquisition card to take readings from a device that increases its signal to a peak and then falls back to near the original value. To find the peak value we currently search the array for the highest reading and use the index to determine the timing of the peak value which is used in our calculations.

This works well if the highest value is the peak we are looking for but if the device is not working correctly we can see a second peak which can be higher than the initial peak. We take 10 readings a second from 16 devices over a 90 second period.

My initial thoughts are to cycle through the readings checking to see if the previous and next points are less than the current to find a peak and construct an array of peaks. Maybe we should be looking at a average of a number of points either side of the current position to allow for noise in the system. Is this the best way to proceed or are there better techniques?##C##<language-agnostic><algorithm><data>##C##@$R$@

3272##C##22211##C##1.02919348375872##C##2763.55327870371##C##0##C##1729##C##0##C##1762##C##Timer-based event triggers##C##I am currently working on a project with specific requirements.  A brief overview of these are as follows:
* Data is retrieved from external webservices
* Data is manipulated via a web GUI
* The windows service that communicates with the web services has no coupling with our internal web UI
column2: except via the database.

column1: * Communication with the web services needs to be both time-based
column2: and triggered via user intervention on the web UI.

column1: The current (pre-pre-production) model for web service communication triggering is via a database table that stores trigger requests generated from the manual intervention.  I do not really want to have multiple trigger mechanisms
column2: but would like to be able to populate the database table with triggers based upon the time of the call.  As I see it there are two ways to accomplish this.

column1: 1) Adapt the trigger table to store two extra parameters.  One being "Is this time-based or manually added?" and a nullable field to store the timing details (exact format to be determined).  If it is a manaully created trigger
column2: mark it as processed when the trigger has been fired
column3: but not if it is a timed trigger.

column1: 2) Create a second windows service that creates the triggers on-the-fly at timed intervals.
The second option seems like a fudge to me
column2: but the management of option 1 could easily turn into a programming nightmare (how do you know if the last poll of the table returned the event that needs to fire
column3: and how do you then stop it re-triggering on the next poll)

column1: I'd appreciate it if anyone could spare a few minutes to help me decide which route (one of these two
column2: or possibly a third
column3: unlisted one) to take.

column1: > connection. If you are running the

We have considered the following options
1. Splitting the page so that credit card collection (the requirement for SSL) is not on the same page as the Google Map.

column2: such as Virtual Earth.  Rumor has it that they support SSL.

3798##C##1974##C##0.0939835645258427##C##2763.23283695616##C##0##C##1348##C##1##C##2109##C##Full complete mysql DB replication? Ideas? What do people do?##C##Currently I have two linux servers wunning MySQL
column2: one sitting on a rack right next to me under a 10Mbit upload pipe (main server) and another some couple of miles away on a 3Mbit upload pipe (mirror).

column1: I want to be able to replicate data on both servers continuously
column2: but have run into several roadblocks. One of them being
column3: under MySQL master/slave configurations
column4: every now and then
column5: some statements drop (!)
column6: meaning; some people logging on to the mirror URL don't see data that I know is on the main server and vice versa. Lets say this happens on a meaningful block of data once every month
column7: so I can live with it and assume its a "lost packet" issue (i.e.
column9: but we'll compensate).

column1: The other most important (and annoying) recurring issue is that
column2: when for some reason we do a major upload or update (or reboot) on one end and have to sever the link
column3: then LOAD DATA FROM MASTER doesn't work and I have to manually dump on one end and upload on the other
column4: quite a task nowadays moving some .5TB worth of data.

column1: Is there software for this? I know MySQL (the "corporation") offers this as a VERY expensive service (full DB replication). Just wondering what people out there do. The way its structured
column2: we run an automatic failover where if one server is not up
column3: then the main URL just resolves to the other server.

column1: 3801##C##89532##C##5.02271744189784##C##2763.23049783567##C##0##C##718##C##0##C##1822##C##Dual vs. Quadcore on a Webserver##C##The discussion of Dual vs. Quadcore is as old as the Quadcores itself and the answer is usually "it depends on your scenario". So here the scenario is a Web Server (Windows 2003 (not sure if x32 or x64)
column2: 4 GB RAM
column3: IIS
column4: ASP.net 3.0).

column1: My impression is that the CPU in a Webserver does not need to be THAT fast because requests are usually rather lightweight
column2: so having more (slower) cores should be a better choice as we got many small requests.

column1: But since I do not have much experience with IIS load balancing and since I don't want to spend a lot of money only to find out I've made the wrong choice
column2: can someone who has a bit more experience comment on whether or not More Slower or Fewer Faster cores is better?##C##<asp.net><windows><iis>##C##@$R$@

One of the reports shows missing (recommended) indexes. I think it's based on some system view that is maintained by the query optimizer.

My question is what is the best way to determine when to take an index recommendation. I know that it doesn't make sense to apply all of the optimizer's suggestions. column2: in hours

column2: I have made a non-primary
column3: non-clustered index on this ID field rather than giving the tables a clustered primary key.

column1: I'm wondering what the performance implications are for this approach. I've seen some people suggest that tables should have an auto-incrementing ("identity") int as a clustered primary key even if it doesn't have any meaning
column2: as it means that the database engine itself can use that value to quickly look up a row instead of having to use a bookmark.

column1: My database is merge-replicated across a bunch of servers
column2: so I've shied away from identity int columns as they're a bit hairy to get right in replication.

5831##C##201038##C##4.09098240779713##C##2761.48463295121##C##0##C##2288##C##1##C##7942##C##Binary patch-generation in C###C##Does anyone have, or know of, a binary patch generation algorithm implementation in C#?

Basically, compare two files (designated *old* and *new*), and produce a patch file that can be used to upgrade the *old* file to have the same contents as the *new* file.

The implementation would have to be relatively fast, and work with huge files. It should exhibit O(n) or O(logn) runtimes.

My own algorithms tend to either be lousy (fast but produce huge patches) or slow (produce small patches but have O(n^2) runtime).

Any advice, or pointers for implementation would be nice.

Specifically, the implementation will be used to keep servers in sync for various large datafiles that we have one master server for. When the master server datafiles change, we need to update several off-site servers as well.

The most naive algorithm I have made, which only works for files that can be kept in memory, is as follows:

1. Grab the first four bytes from the *old* file, call this the *key*
2. Add those bytes to a dictionary, where *key -> position*, where *position* is the position where I grabbed those 4 bytes, 0 to begin with
3. Skip the first of these four bytes, grab another 4 (3 overlap, 1 one), and add to the dictionary the same way
4. Repeat steps 1-3 for all 4-byte blocks in the *old* file
5. From the start of the *new* file, grab 4 bytes, and attempt to look it up in the dictionary
6. If found, find the longest match if there are several, by comparing bytes from the two files
7. Encode a reference to that location in the *old* file, and skip the matched block in the *new* file
8. If not found, encode 1 byte from the *new* file, and skip it
9. Repeat steps 5-8 for the rest of the *new* file

This is somewhat like compression, without windowing, so it will use a lot of memory. It is, however, fairly fast, and produces quite small patches, as long as I try to make the codes output minimal.

A more memory-efficient algorithm uses windowing, but produces much bigger patch files.

There are more nuances to the above algorithm that I skipped in this post, but I can post more details if necessary. I do, however, feel that I need a different algorithm altogether, so improving on the above algorithm is probably not going to get me far enough.##C##<c#><patchgeneration><file>##C##@$R$@
5842##C##11411##C##0.0180025808513165##C##2761.47860378493##C##0##C##927##C##1##C##21130##C##Issues using MS Access as a front-end to a MySQL database back-end?##C##Two users wanted to share the same database, originally written in MS Access, without conflicting with one another over a single MDB file.

I moved the tables from a simple MS Access database to MySQL using its [Migration Toolkit][1] (which works well, by the way) and set up Access to link to those tables via ODBC.

So far, I've run into the following:

   * You can't insert/update/delete rows in a table without a primary key (no surprise there).
   * AutoNumber fields in MS Access must be the primary key or they'll just end up as integer columns in MySQL (natch, why wouldn't it be the PK?)
   * The tables were migrated to MySQL's InnoDB table type, but the Access relationships didn't become MySQL foreign key constraints.

Once the database is in use, can I expect any other issues? Particularly when both users are working in the same table?

  [1]: http://www.mysql.com/products/tools/migration-toolkit/##C##<database><mysql><ms-access>##C##@$R$@

5949##C##11411##C##0.0770319793373346##C##2761.41957438644##C##1##C##1611##C##2##C##12744##C##What's your opinion on using UUIDs as database row identifiers
column2: particularly in web apps?##C##I've always preferred to use long integers as primary keys in databases
column3: for simplicity and (assumed) speed. But when using a [REST][1] or Rails-like URL scheme for object instances
column4: I'd then end up with URLs like this:

column1: And then the assumption is that there are also users with IDs of 782
column5: and 1. Assuming that the web app in question is secure enough to prevent people entering other numbers to view other users without authorization
column6: a simple sequentially-assigned surrogate key also "leaks" the total number of instances (older than this one)
column7: in this case users

column1: Would a [UUID][2]/GUID be a better solution? Then I could set up URLs like this:

column2: but there's less implied information about users on display. Sure
column3: it smacks of "security through obscurity" which is no substitute for proper security
column4: but it seems at least a little more secure.

column1: Is that benefit worth the cost and complexity of implementing UUIDs for web-addressable object instances? I think that I'd still want to use integer columns as database PKs just to speed up joins.

There's also the question of in-database representation of UUIDs. I know MySQL stores them as 36-character strings. Postgres seems to have a more efficient internal representation (128 bits?) but I haven't tried it myself. Anyone have any experience with this?

column2: I've written an API to www.thetvdb.com in Python. The current code can be found [here](http://github.com/dbr/tvdb_api/tree/master/tvdb_api.py).

column1: It grabs data from the API as requested
column2: and has to store the data somehow
column3: and make it available by doing:

column1: print tvdbinstance[1][23]['episodename'] # get the name of episode 23 of season 1
What is the "best" way to abstract this data in the Tvdb() class?
I originally used a extended Dict() that automatically created sub-dicts (so you could do `x[1][2][3][4] = "something"` without having to do `if x[1].has_key(2): x[1][2] = []` and so on)

column2: but there was no easy way of checking if x[3][24] was supposed to exist or not (so I couldn't raise the season_not_found exception)

column1: Currently it's using four classes. ShowContainer
column2: Show
column3: Season and Episode. Each one is a very basic dict
column4: which I can easily add extra functionality in (the search() function on Show() for example). Each has a `__setitem__`
column5: `__getitem_` and `has_key`

column2: I can check in Shows if it has that season in it's self.data dict
column3: if not
column4: raise season_not_found. Check in Season() if it has that episode and so on.

column1: The problem now is it's presenting itself as a dict
column2: but doesn't have all the functionality
column3: and because I'm overriding the __getitem__ and __setitem__ functions
column4: it's easy to accidently recursively call __getitem__ (so I'm not sure if extending the Dict class will cause problems)

column1: The other slight problem is adding data into the dict is a lot more work than the old Ddict method (which was `self.data[seas_no][ep_no]['attribute'] = 'something'`). See _setItem and _setData. It's not too bad
column2: since it's currently only a read-only API interface (so the users of the API should only ever retrieve data
column3: not add more)
column4: but it's hardly.. elegant..

column1: I think the series-of-classes system is probably the best way
column2: but does anyone have a better idea for storing the data? And would extending the ShowContainer/etc classes with Dict cause problems?##C##<python><datastructure>##C##@$R$@

Are there any other methods that you've found that might be of use to me and anybody else that's hit the same problem?

Example, all on one line:

    if (var1 = true && var2 = true && var2 = true && var3 = true && var4 = true && var5 = true && var6 = true)
    {

Example, multi-line:

    if (var1 = true && var2 = true && var2 = true

6130##C##2214##C##0.0222660531289876##C##2761.29910443304##C##1##C##832##C##0##C##55016##C##Repair SVN Checksum##C##I'm using subclipse in Flex Builder 3, and recently received this error when trying to commit:

`svn: Checksum mismatch for '/Users/redacted/Documents/Flex Builder 3/path/to/my/file.mxml'; expected: 'f8cb275de72776657406154dd3c10348', actual: 'null'`

I worked around it by:

 1. Committing all the other changed files, omitting the troublesome one.
 2. Copying the contents of the trouble file to a TextMate window
 3. Deleting my project in FlexBuilder/Eclipse
 4. Checking my project out fresh from SVN
 5. Copying the text of the trouble file back in from the TextMate Window
 6. Committing the changes.

It worked, but I can't help but think there's a better way. What's actaully happening to cause the svn:checksum error, and what's the best fix.

Maybe more important -- is this a symptom of a greater problem?##C##<subclipse><subversion>##C##@$R$@

test
column3: and production?##C##I've had a hard time trying to find good examples of how to manage database schemas and data between development
column4: test
column5: and production servers.

column1: Here's our setup. Each developer has a virtual machine running our app and the MySQL database. It is their personal sandbox to do whatever they want. Currently
column2: developers will make a change to the SQL schema and do a dump of the database to a text file that they commit into SVN.

column1: We're wanting to deploy a continuous integration development server that will always be running the latest committed code. If we do that now
column2: it will reload the database from SVN for each build.

column1: We have a test (virtual) server that runs "release candidates." Deploying to the test server is currently a very manual process
column2: and usually involves me loading the latest SQL from SVN and tweaking it. Also
column3: the data on the test server is inconsistent. You end up with whatever test data the last developer to commit had on his sandbox server.

column1: Where everything breaks down is the deployment to production. Since we can't overwrite the live data with test data
column2: this involves manually re-creating all the schema changes. If there were a large number of schema changes or conversion scripts to manipulate the data
column3: this can get really hairy.

column1: If the problem was just the schema
column2: It'd be an easier problem
column3: but there is "base" data in the database that is updated during development as well
column4: such as meta-data in security and permissions tables.

column1: This is the biggest barrier I see in moving toward continuous integration and one-step-builds. How do ***you*** solve it?##C##<mysql><svn><bestpractices>##C##@$R$@

6378##C##12301##C##4.16542052058503##C##2761.12626038212##C##0##C##1171##C##1##C##454##C##what client(s) should be targeted in implementing an iCalendar export for events?##C##[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ICalendar][1]
I'm working to implement an export feature for events. The link above lists tons of clients that support the ICalendar standard
column2: but the "three big ones" I can see are Apple's iCal
column3: Microsoft's Outlook
column4: and Google's Gmail.

column1: I'm starting to get the feeling that each of these client implement different parts of the "standard"
column2: and I'm unsure of what pieces of information we should be trying to export from the application so that someone can put it on their calendar (especially around recurrence).
from what I understand Outlook doesn't support daily recurrence (an event happens more than once per day).

column1: Could any of you provide guidance of the "happy medium" here from a features implementation standpoint?

column2: if we decide to cut features from the export (such as daily recurrence) because it isn't supported in Outlook
column3: should we support it in the application as well? (it is a general purpose event scheduling application
column4: with no business specific use in mind...so we really are looking for the happy medium).

column2: Proxy Classes and Type Conversion##C##as you can probably tell from my rep
column3: I have just got my invite so I am a complete n00b! :D First off I would like to say thanks to Jeff and the team for what looks like is going to be an **excellent** site for the community.

column2: my question:

column1: I am still kinda new to the ASP.NET world
column2: so I could be way off base here
column3: but so far this is to the best of my (limited) knowledge!

column1: Lets say I have a standard business object.. "Contact" in the *Business* namespace.. I write a Web Service to retrieve a Contact's info from a database
column2: and return it. I then write a client application to request said details.
I also then create a utility method that takes a "Contact" and does some magic with it
column3: like *Utils.BuyContactNewHat()* say.. Which of course takes the Contact of type *Business.Contact*.

column1: I then go back to my client application and want to utilise the *BuyContactNewHat* method
column2: so I add a reference to my *Utils* namespace and there it is. However
column3: a problem arises with:

column1: Since the return type of *GetContact* is of *MyWebService.Contact* and not *Business.Contact* as expected.

column2: because when accessing a web service
column3: you are actually programming against the proxy class generated by the WSDL..

column2: is there an "easier" way to deal with this type mismatch? I was considering perhaps trying to create a generic converter class that uses reflection to ensure two objects have the same structure
column3: then simply transferring the values across from one to the other..

column2: sorry for the long question

column1: 7015##C##41183##C##3.69622296281159##C##2759.86968568293##C##0##C##971##C##0##C##1422##C##Multicore Text File Parsing##C##I have a quad core machine and would like to write some code to parse a text file that takes advantage of all four cores. The text file basically contains one record per line.
Multithreading isn't my forte so I'm wondering if anyone could give me some patterns that I might be able to use to parse the file in an optimal manner.
My first thoughts are to read all the lines into some sort of queue and then spin up threads to pull the lines off the queue and process them
column2: but that means the queue would have to exist in memory and these are faily large files so I'm not so keen on that idea.

column1: My next thoughts are to have some sort of controller that will read in a line and assign it a thread to parse
column2: but I'm not sure if the controller will end up being a bottleneck if the threads are processing the lines faster than it can read and assign them.

column1: I know there's probably another simpler solution than both of these but at the moment I'm just not seeing it.##C##<c#><threading><multithreaded><quadcore>##C##@$R$@

7174##C##3625##C##0.184368981514126##C##2759.49156003492##C##0##C##1447##C##1##C##422##C##How can I improve the edit-compile-test loop when developing a SharePoint workflow?##C##Recently I had to develop a SharePoint workflow
column2: and I found the experience quite honestly the most painful programming task I've ever had to tackle. One big problem I had was the problems I encountered when I had to step through it in the debugger.

column1: There's an article on how to debug a SharePoint workflow [here][1] that tells you how to set breakpoints etc. This involves copying the .pdb file into the GAC alongside the .dll file containing your workflow. You have to do this from a command prompt (or a batch file) because Windows Explorer doesn't let you view the relevant subdirectory of c:\windows\assembly.

column2: if you do this
column3: the next time you try to deploy the workflow from within Visual Studio
column4: it complains that it can't be deployed because "the file may not be signed" and if you attempt to copy the new version of the dll into the GAC
column5: it tells you that the .dll file is locked.

column1: I've found that some of the time
column2: you can get round this by doing an iisreset
column3: but on other occasions you have to restart Visual Studio and there have been frequent times when I've even had to reboot the computer altogether because some mystery process has locked the file. When I don't use the debugger
column4: on the other hand
column5: everything works just fine.

column1: Does anyone know of a simpler way of debugging workflows than this?

column1: 7492##C##5073##C##4.42503457190469##C##2758.87468799762##C##0##C##1500##C##2##C##100829##C##How do you stress test a web application?##C##Stress testing is something that gets very little love in most death mar..
column2: er I mean web projects. It's usually done at the last minute (or not at all)
column3: next to no time gets allocated to it
column4: etc.

column1: In the past I've picked a tool
column2: installed it on my machine first
column3: hit the home page
column4: upping the concurrency settings. Then I'd write a simple login script
column5: a simple site walkthrough (in an ecommerce site adding a few items to a cart and checkout). Then I'd rope in as many developers as I could
column6: install the stress test tool on their machines and do a massive attack. If nothing broke I'd give up and wait for the actual traffic to kill the site for real.

column1: Just hitting the homepage hard almost always would locate a major problem. More scalability problems would surface at the second stage
column2: and even more - after the launch.

column1: The tools I used were Microsoft Homer (aka Microsoft Web Application Stress Tool) and Pylot.
The reports that these tools generated never made much sense to me

column2: you cannot put an absolutely positioned div over a select input element. That's because the select element is considered an ActiveX object and is on top of every HTML element in the page.

column1: I already saw people hiding selects when opening a popup div
column2: that leads to pretty bad user experience having controls disappearing.

column1: FogBugz actually had a pretty smart solution (before v6) of turning every select into text boxes when a popup was displayed. This solved the bug and tricked the user eye but the behavior was not perfect.
Another solution is in FogBugz 6 where they no more use the select element and recoded it everywhere.
Last solution I currently use is messing up the IE rendering engine and force it to render the absolutely positioned div as an ActiveX element too
column2: ensuring it can live over a select element. This is achieved by placing an invisible iframe inside the div and styling it with:

column2: assuming an easy BPM (beats per minute) of 120
column3: the timer should tick every .5 seconds (or 500 milliseconds).  Using this as the basis for the ticks
column4: however
column5: isn't entirely accurate as .NET only guarantees that your timer will not tick before the elapsed time has passed.

column2: to get around this for the same 120 BPM example used above
column3: I am setting the ticks to something like 100 milliseconds and only playing the click sound on every 5th timer tick.  This does improve the accuracy quite a bit
column4: but if feels like a bit of a hack.

column2: what is the best way to get accurate ticks?  I know there are more timers available than the windows forms timer that is readily available in Visual Studio
column3: but I'm not really familiar with them.##C##<.net><timer>##C##@$R$@

column2: but let's just say that my preference is 64bit and that I have some [very][2] [good][3] reasons.

column3: but since the original [Windows port][5] is Win32 specific
column4: this is hardly going to help when installing as a service on x64. It also has a dependency on the [libevent][7] for which I can only get a Win32 compiled version.

I have a flash applet that needs to maintain a TCP connection to a server. I have implemented timeouts using Timers
column2: a ping-pong system
column3: etc. However
column4: there's a problem. Upon calling Socket.connect()
column5: the flash player (9.0.115 and many other stables before that) sends 3 connection requests by way of SYN packets
column6: with some time in between. If none of those are replied to (e.g. because the server is down)
column7: I cannot get the applet to [attempt to] connect to the server. Ever. That is
column8: within the lifetime of the applet.

column1: For any host/port pair given to Socket.connect() or XMLSocket.connect()
column2: if the call fails
column3: any subsequent connect() calls to any other Socket (or XMLSocket) instances **within the lifetime of the Flash applet** to the same host/port pair get ignored. (At least as far as I can tell using a packet sniffer.)

column1: I have tried calling numerous Socket methods
column2: destroying and recreating the objects
column3: using a pool of Sockets
column4: and various other methods I can't remember right now; all to no avail.

column1: My current solution is to notify the parent webpage through a JavaScript call and let it reload my applet. It's not a pretty solution
column2: and I'm not about to implement workarounds for the problems *it* causes
column3: just because Flash can't handle socket connections properly.

column1: I must be missing something very simple.

1: I know you can't really destroy objects; I just remove all references to them and hope for the best. I haven't tried to explicitly invoke the GC in this case. column1: 9191##C##6221##C##4.18191033555195##C##2757.17345555546##C##0##C##2192##C##0##C##5114##C##How to obtain good concurrent read performance from disk.##C##I'd like to ask a question then follow it up with my own answer
column2: but also see what answers other people have.

column1: We have two large files which we'd like to read from two separate threads concurrently.  One thread will sequentially read fileA while the other thread will sequentially read fileB.  There is no locking or communication between the threads
column2: both are sequentially reading as fast as they can
column3: and both are immediately discarding the data they read.

column1: Our experience with this setup on Windows is very poor.  The combined throughput of the two threads is in the order of 2-3 MiB/sec.  The drive seems to be spending most of its time seeking backwards and forwards between the two files
column2: presumably reading very little after each seek.

column1: If we disable one of the threads and temporarily look at the performance of a single thread then we get much better bandwidth (~45 MiB/sec for this machine).  So clearly the bad two-thread performance is an artefact of the OS disk scheduler.
**Is there anything we can do to improve the concurrent thread read performance?**  Perhaps by using different APIs or by tweaking the OS disk scheduler parameters in some way.

The files are in the order of 2 GiB each on a machine with 2GiB of RAM.  For the purpose of this question we consider them not to be cached and perfectly defragmented.  We have used defrag tools and rebooted to ensure this is the case.
We are using no special APIs to read these files.  The behaviour is repeatable across various bog-standard APIs such as Win32's CreateFile
column2: C's fopen
column3: C++'s std::ifstream
column4: Java's FileInputStream
column5: etc.

column1: Each thread spins in a loop making calls to the read function.  We have varied the number of bytes requested from the API each iteration from values between 1KiB up to 128MiB.  Varying this has had no effect
column2: so clearly the amount the OS is physically reading after each disk seek is not dictated by this number.  This is exactly what should be expected.

column1: The dramatic difference between one-thread and two-thread performance is repeatable across Windows 2000
column2: Windows XP (32-bit and 64-bit)
column3: Windows Server 2003
column4: and also with and without hardware RAID5.##C##<windows><multithreading><file-io>##C##@$R$@

9240##C##2048##C##0.0873157754540443##C##2757.1203859956##C##0##C##1315##C##0##C##1443##C##Interfaces on different logic layers##C##Say you have an application divided into 3-tiers. GUI
column2: business logic and data access. In your business logic layer you have described your business objects. Getters
column3: accessors and so on... you get the idea. The interface to the business logic layer guarantees safe usage of the business logic
column4: so all the methods and accessors you call will validate input.

column1: This great when you write the UI code
column2: because you have a neatly defined interface that you can trust.

column1: But here comes the tricky part
column2: when you start writing the data access layer
column3: the interface to the business logic does not accomodate your needs. You need to have more accessors and getters to set fields which are used to be hidden. Now you are forced to erode the interface of your business logic. Now it is possible set fields from the UI layer which the UI layer has no business setting.

column1: Because of the changes needed for the data access layer
column2: the interface to the business logic has eroded to the point where it is possible to even set the business logic with invalid data. Thus
column3: the interface does not guarantee safe usage anymore.

column1: I hope I explained the problem clearly enough. How do you prevent interface eroding
column2: maintain information hiding and encapsulation and still accomodate different interface needs among different layers? ##C##<architecture>##C##@$R$@

column1: 9675##C##13##C##5.43892383575439e-07##C##2756.50747395819##C##0##C##1609##C##0##C##241##C##Document Server: Handling Concurrent Saves##C##I'm implementing a document server. Currently
column2: if two users open the same document
column3: modify it and save the changes
column4: document's state will be undefined (either the first user's changes are saved permanently
column5: or the second's). This is entirely unsatisfactory. I considered two possibilities to solve this problem.

column1: The first is to lock document when it is opened by someone the first time
column2: and unlock it when it is closed. But if network connection to the server is suddenly interrupted
column3: the document would stay in forever-locked state. The obvious solution is to send regular pings to the server. If server doesn't receive K pings in a row (K > 1) from a particular client
column4: documents locked by this client are unlocked. If that client re-appears
column5: documents are locked again
column6: if someone hadn't already locked them. This could also help if the client application (running in web browser) is terminated unexpectedly
column7: making it impossible to send 'quitting
column8: unlock my documents' signal to the server.

column1: The second is to store multiple versions of the same document saved by different users. If changes to the document are made in a rapid succession
column2: system would offer either to merge versions or to select preferred version. To optimize storage space
column3: only document diffs should be kept. (Just like source control software).

column2: taking into consideration that the connection to the server might *sometimes* be slow and unresponsive? How should the parameters (ping interval
column3: rapid succession interval) be determined?

column2: I can't store the documents in a database.##C##<versioning><document-server><locking><concurrent>##C##@$R$@

column1: 9702##C##144##C##5.32250851392746e-07##C##2756.48358954862##C##1##C##1931##C##0##C##280##C##Default database IDs; system and user values##C##As part of our current database work
column2: we are looking at a dealing with the process of updating databases.

column1: A point which has been brought up recurrently
column2: is that of dealing with system vs. user values; in our project user and system vals are stored together. For example...

column1: We have a list of templates.

column2: <system template>
<system template>
<system template>

column1: These are mapped in the app to an enum (1
Then a user comes in and adds...

column2: <user template>
<user template>

column1: Then.. we issue an upgrade.. and insert as part of our upgrade scripts...

column2: <new system template>

column1: THEN!!... we find a bug in the new system template and need to update it... The problem is how? We cannot update record using ID6 (as we may have inserted it as 9
column2: or 999
column3: so we have to identify the record using some other mechanism)

column2: we've come to two possible solutions for this.

column1: We simply start user Ids at 5000 (or some other value) and test data at 10000 (or some other value). This would allow us to make modifications to system values and test them up to the lower limit of the next ID range.
Disadvantage... could run out of values if we don't choose a big enough range!

column2: system and user data separately
column3: use GUIDs as Ids and merge the two lists using a view.

column1: Advantage...Scalable..No limits w/regard to DB size.
Disadvantage.. More complicated to implement. (many to one updatable views etc.)
I plump squarely for the first option
column2: but looking for some ammo to back me up!

column1: Does anyone have any thoughts on these approaches
column2: or even one(s) that we've missed?

column1: 9926##C##41532##C##0.19997342582792##C##2756.36815096065##C##0##C##869##C##1##C##1843##C##Analyzing Multithreaded Programs##C##We have a codebase that is several years old
column2: and all the original developers are long gone.  It uses many
column3: many threads
column4: but with no apparent design or common architectural principles.  Every developer had his own style of multithreaded programming
column5: so some threads communicate with one another using queues
column6: some lock data with mutexes
column7: some lock with semaphores
column8: some use operating-system IPC mechanisms for intra-process communications.  There is no design documentation
column9: and comments are sparse.  It's a mess
column10: and it seems that whenever we try to refactor the code or add new functionality
column11: we introduce deadlocks or other problems.

column2: does anyone know of any tools or techniques that would help to analyze and document all the interactions between threads?  FWIW
column3: the codebase is C++ on Linux
column4: but I'd be interested to hear about tools for other environments.##C##<threads><multithreaded><threading><softwaretools>##C##@$R$@

column1: 10323##C##30993##C##0.335778587963432##C##2756.15335871512##C##1##C##818##C##1##C##17673##C##why doesn't Ruby have a real StringBuffer or StringIO##C##I recently read a nice [post][1] on using `StringIO` in Ruby.  What the author doesn't mention
column2: though
column3: is that `StringIO` is just an "I."  There's no "O."  You _can't_ do this
column4: for example:

column1: s.tos         # I mean with an underscore
column2: but Markdown hates that

column1: Ruby really needs a StringBuffer just like the one Java has. StringBuffers serve two important purposes. First
column2: they let you test the output half of what Ruby's StringIO does. Second
column3: they are useful for building up long strings from small parts -- something that Joel reminds us over and over again is otherwise very very slow.

10860##C##22211##C##9.01517655095086##C##2755.56729563652##C##0##C##1155##C##0##C##2985##C##Data Layer Best Practices##C##I am in the middle of a "discussion" with a colleague about the best way to implement the data layer in a new application.
One viewpoint is that the data layer should be aware of business objects (our own classes that represent an entity)
column2: and be able to work with that object natively.

column1: The opposing viewpoint is that the data layer should be object-agnostic
column2: and purely handle simple data types (strings
column3: bools
column4: dates
column5: etc.)

column1: I can see that both approaches may be valid
column2: but my own viewpoint is that I prefer the former.  That way
column3: if the data storage medium changes
column4: the business layer doesn't (necessarily) have to change to accommodate the new data layer.  It would therefore be a trivial thing to change from a SQL data store to a serialized xml filesystem store.

column1: My colleague's point of view is that the data layer shouldn't have to know about object definitions
column2: and that as long as the data is passed about appropriately
column3: that is enough.

column2: I know that this is one of those questions that has the potential to start a religious war
column3: but I'd appreciate any feedback from the community on how you approach such things.

column1: 10901##C##3255##C##1.07405636552721##C##2755.5235794792##C##0##C##1630##C##0##C##3436##C##Future proofing a large UI Application - MFC with 2008 Feature pack
column2: or C# and Winforms?##C##My company has developed a long standing product using MFC in Visual C++ as the defacto standard for UI development. Our codebase contains ALOT of legacy/archaic code which must be kept operational. Some of this code is older than me (originally written in the late 70s) and some members of our team are still on Visual Studio 6.
a conclusion has thankfully been reached internally that our product is looking somewhat antiquated compared to our competitors'
column3: and that something needs to be done.

column1: I am currently working on a new area of the UI which is quite separate from the rest of the product. I have therefore been given the chance to try out 'new' technology stacks as a sort of proving ground before the long process of moving over the rest of the UI begins.
I have been using C# with Windows Forms and the .net framework for a while in my spare time and enjoy it
column2: but am somewhat worried about the headaches caused by interop. While this particular branch of the UI won't require much interop with the legacy C++ codebase
column3: I can forsee this becoming an issue in the future.

column1: The alternative is just to continue with MFC
column2: but try and take advantage of the new feature pack that shipped with VS2008. This I guess is the easiest option
column3: but I worry about longevity and not taking advantage of the goodness that is .net...

column2: which do I pick? We're a small team so my recommendation will quite probably be accepted as a future direction for our development - I want to get it right.

column1: Is MFC dead? Is C#/Winforms the way forward? Is there anything else I'm totally missing? Help greatly appreciated!

column2: but I've been spinning my wheels for some time on this one. I am dealing with a legacy db which really can't be altered structurally. I have a details table which lists payment plans that have been accepted by a customer. Each payment plan has an ID which links back to a reference table to get the plan's terms
column3: conditions
column4: etc. In my object model
column5: I have an AcceptedPlan class
column6: and a Plan class. Originally
column7: I used a many-to-one relationship from the detail table back to the ref table to model this relationship in NHibernate. I also created a one-to-many relationship going in the opposite direction from the Plan class over to the AcceptedPlan class. This was fine while I was simply reading data. I could go to my Plan object
column8: which was a property of my AcceptedPlan class to read the plan's details. My problem arose when I had to start inserting new rows to the details table. From my reading
column9: it seems the only way to create a new child object is to add it to the parent object and then save the session. But I don't want to have to create a new parent Plan object every time I want to create a new detail record. This seems like unnecessary overhead. Does anyone know if I am going about this in the wrong way?##C##<c#><nhibernate>##C##@$R$@

column2: I'm caching the data retrieved from each call to the webservice for a page of data.

column1: There are several things that can expire my cache.  Filtering and sorting are the main reason.  However
column2: a user may edit a row of data in the grid by opening an editor.  The data they edit could cause the data displayed in the row to be stale.  I could easily go to the webservice and get the whole page of data
column3: but since the page size is set at runtime I could be looking at a large amount of records to retrieve.

column1: So let me now get to the heart of the issue that I am experiencing.  In order to prevent getting the whole page of data back I make a call to the webservice asking for the completely updated record (the editor handles saving its data).

Since I'm using custom objects I need to serialize them on the server to XML (this is handled already for other portions of our software).  All data is handled through XML in e4x.  The cache in the Dictionary is stored as an XMLList.
Now let me show you my code...

column2: I get the id of the node I want to replace.  Then I find it in the cache's Data property (XMLList).  I make sure it exists since the filter on the second line returns the XMLList.

column1: The problem I have is with the delete line.  I cannot make that line delete that node from the list.  The line following the delete line works.  I've added the node to the list.
How do I replace or delete that node (meaning the node that I find from the filter statement out of the .Data property of the cache)???

column2: with lots of arrays and other class object members.  I need to be able to generate a deep clone of this object - so I write a Clone() method
column3: and implement it with a simple BinaryFormatter serialize/deserialize - or perhaps I do the deep clone using some other technique which is more error prone and I'd like to make sure is tested.

column2: so now (ok
column3: I should have done it first) I'd like write tests which cover the cloning.  All the members of the class are private
column4: and my architecture is so good (!) that I haven't needed to write hundreds of public properties or other accessors.  The class isn't IComparable or IEquatable
column5: because that's not needed by the application.  My unit tests are in a separate assembly to the production code.

column1: What approaches do people take to testing that the cloned object is a good copy?   Do you write (or *rewrite* once you discover the need for the clone) all your unit tests for the class so that they can be invoked with *either* a 'virgin' object *or* with a clone of it?   How would you test if part of the cloning wasn't deep enough - as this is just the kind of problem which can give hideous-to-find bugs later?

column1: 11060##C##29473##C##4.15955712972209##C##2755.41711188667##C##0##C##1203##C##0##C##4041##C##How should I unit test a code-generator?##C##This is a difficult and open-ended question I know
column2: but I thought I'd throw it to the floor and see if anyone had any interesting suggestions.

column1: I have developed a code-generator that takes our python interface to our C++ code (generated via SWIG) and generates code needed to expose this as WebServices.  When I developed this code I did it using TDD
column2: but I've found my tests to be brittle as hell.  Because each test essentially wanted to verify that for a given bit of input code (which happens to be a C++ header) I'd get a given bit of outputted code I wrote a small engine that reads test definitions from XML input files and generates test cases from these expectations.

column1: The problem is I dread going in to modify the code at all.  That and the fact that the unit tests themselves are a: complex
column2: and b: brittle.

column1: So I'm trying to think of alternative approaches to this problem
column2: and it strikes me I'm perhaps tackling it the wrong way.  Maybe I need to focus more on the outcome
column3: IE: does the code I generate actually run and do what I want it to
column4: rather than
column5: does the code look the way I want it to.

column1: Has anyone got any experiences of something similar to this they would care to share?##C##<c++><python><unittesting><swig><codegeneration>##C##@$R$@

column1: 11152##C##1484##C##3.07938275486231##C##2755.37742913188##C##0##C##1673##C##1##C##1153##C##How do I create a workflow instance reliably based on an external event?##C##a little new to the windows workflow stuff so go easy :)
I wish to design a workflow host environment that has high availability - a minimum of 2 WF runtime hosts on separate hardware both pointing to the same persistance or tracking SQL database.

I am looking for a pattern whereby I can asynchronously create new workflow instances based on some external event (i.e. some piece of data is updated in DB by a different application). For each event I need to create exactly one workflow instance and doesn't matter which host that instance is created on. There is also some flexibility regarding the duration of time between the event and when the workflow instance is actually created.

One solution I am considering is having a WCF interface on the WF hosts and placing them behind some sort of load balancer. It would then be up to whatever part of the system that is firing the "event" to make the WCF call.
I'm not really happy with this because if both\all WF hosts are down
column2: or otherwise unavailable
column3: the event could be "lost". Also
column4: I won't be able manage load the way I would like to. I envisage a situation where there may be lots of events in a small period of time
column5: but it's perfectly acceptable to handle those events some time later.

column1: So I reckon I need to persist the events somehow and decouple the event creation from the event handling.
Is putting these events into MSMQ
column2: or a simple event table in SQL Server
column3: and having the WF host just poll the queue periodically a viable solution? Polling seems to be a such a dirty word though...

column1: Would NServiceBus and durable messaging be useful here?
Any insights would be much appreciated.

11689##C##30993##C##1.35732997674495##C##2755.13180732634##C##1##C##1150##C##0##C##323##C##Design debate: versioned temporal objects##C##I am intentionally leaving this quite vague at first.  I'm looking for discussion and what issues are important more than I'm looking for hard answers.
I'm in the middle of designing an app that does something like portfolio management.  The design I have so far is
* Problem: a problem that needs to be solved
* Solution: a proposed solution to one or more problems
* Relationship: a relationship among two problems
column2: two solutions
column3: or a problem and a solution.  Further broken down into:

column1: * Parent-child - some sort of categorization / tree hierarchy
* Overlap - the degree to which two solutions or two problems really address the same concept
* Addresses - the degree to which a problem addresses a solution
My question is about the temporal nature of these things.  Problems crop up
column2: then fade.  Solutions have an expected resolution date
column3: but that might be modified as they are developed.  The degree of a relationship might change over time as problems and solutions evolve.

column2: the question: what is the best design for versioning of these things so I can get both a current and an historical perspective of my portfolio?##C##<time><design><portfolio-management><risk-management>##C##@$R$@

11854##C##3448##C##1.0716462964192##C##2754.95778136561##C##0##C##865##C##0##C##1481##C##Inheritance and Polymorphism - Ease of use vs Purity##C##In a project our team is using object lists to perform mass operations on sets of data that should all be processed in a similar way.  In particular
column2: different objects would ideally act the same
column3: which would be very easily achieved with polymorphism.  The problem I have with it is that inheritance implies the _is a_ relationship
column4: rather than the _has a_ relationship.  For example
column5: several objects _have a_ damage counter
column6: but to make this easy to use in an object list
column7: polymorphism could be used - except that would imply an _is a_ relationship which wouldn't be true.  (A person _is not_ a damage counter.)

column1: The only solution I can think of is to have a member of the class return the proper object type when implicitly casted instead of relying on inheritance.  **Would it be better to forgo the _is a_ / _has a_ ideal in exchange for ease of programming?**##C##<inheritance><polymorphism><oop>##C##@$R$@

column2: e.g.
column3: a certain complicated calculation. Those non-UI objects are unit-tested
column4: but also need access to lots of those global settings. The way we've implemented this right now
column5: is by giving the objects properties that are filled by the Application Controller at runtime. When testing
column6: we create the objects in the test and fill in values for testing (not from the database).

column2: in any case much better than having all those objects need some global _Settings_ object --- that of course effectively makes unit testing impossible :) Disadvantage can be that you sometimes need to set a dozen of properties
column3: or that you need to let those properties 'percolate' into sub-objects.

column1: **So the general question is**: how do you provide access to global application settings in your projects
column2: without the need for global variables
column3: while still being able to unit test your code? This must be a problem that's been solved 100's of times...

column1: Let's say you have a maintenance plan with a task to check the database
column2: something like this:
all_errormsgs

column1: If you go look in your logs after the task executes
column2: you might see something like this:
spid55
column3: Unknown
column4: DBCC CHECKDB (mssqlsystemresource) executed by NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM found 0 errors and repaired 0 errors. Elapsed time: 0 hours 0 minutes 0 seconds.

column2: spid55
column3: Unknown
column4: DBCC CHECKDB (master) executed by NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM found 0 errors and repaired 0 errors. Elapsed time: 0 hours 0 minutes 0 seconds.

column2: it checked master and msssqlsystemresource.

column1: My workaround is to create a Sql Server Agent Job with this:

column2: all_errormsgs;
spid54
column3: Unknown
column4: DBCC CHECKDB (MyDb) WITH all_errormsgs<c/> no_infomsgs executed by NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM found 0 errors and repaired 0 errors. Elapsed time: 0 hours 26 minutes 3 seconds.

column2: which only really get tested in anger when our product is rolled out to a large number of users.

column1: What makes this worse is that some of these stored procedures end up being very long
column2: because of the performance hit when passing temporary tables between SPs. This has prevented us from refactoring to make the code simpler.

column1: We have made several attempts at building unit tests around some of our key stored procedures (primarily testing the performance)
column2: but have found that setting up the test data for these tests is really hard. For example
column3: we end up copying around test databases. In addition to this
column4: the tests end up being really sensitive to change
column5: and even the smallest change to a stored proc. or table requires a large amount of changes to the tests. So after many builds breaking due to these database tests failing intermittently
column6: weve just had to pull them out of the build process.

column2: the main part of my questions is: has anyone ever successfully written unit tests for their stored procedures?

column1: So the actual audit table will have 3 columns (this design may change but for this question it doesn't matter); who (Active Directory User)

column2: however I don't know how I could grab the Active Directory User that way.  An alternate would be to code it directly into the Access source so that whenever something changes I run an INSERT statement.  Obviously that is flawed because if something happens to Access or the database is touched by something else then it will not log the audit.
examples or articles that may help me would be greatly appreciated!

column1: 12815##C##9161##C##2.13480145856738##C##2754.08176420117##C##0##C##1006##C##0##C##1989##C##Anyone Using Executable Requirements?##C##In my limited experience with them executable requirements (i.e. specifying all requirements as broken automated tests) have proven to be amazingly successful.  I've worked on one project in which we placed a heavy emphasis on creating high-level automated tests which exercised all the functionality of a given use case/user story.  It was really amazing to me how much easier development became after we began this practice.  Implementing features became so much easier after writing a test and we were able to make major architectural changes to the system with all the confidence in the world that everything still worked the same as it did yesterday.
The biggest problem we ran into was that the tools for managing these types of tests aren't very good.  We used Fitnesse quite a bit and as a result I now hate the Fit framework.

I'd like to know 1) if anyone else has experience developing using this type of test-driven requirement definition and 2) what tools you all used to facilitate this.##C##<automation><process><test><executablerequirements>##C##@$R$@

12982##C##4389##C##0.510476088151336##C##2753.83443649299##C##0##C##1676##C##0##C##1076##C##What is your preferred method of sending complex data over a web service?##C##It's 2008
column2: and I'm still torn on this one.  So I'm developing a web method that needs a complex type passed into it and returned from it.  The two options I'm toying with are:

column1: 1. Pass and return *actual* business objects with both data and behavior.  When wsdl.exe is run
column2: it will automatically create proxy classes that contain just the data portion
column3: and these will be automatically converted to and from my real business objects on the server side.  On the client side
column4: they will only get to use the dumb proxy type
column5: and they will have to map them into some real business objects as they see fit.  A big drawback here is that if I "own" both the server and client side
column6: and I want to use the same set of real business objects
column7: I can run into certain headaches with name conflicts
column8: etc.  (Since the real objects and the proxies are named the same.)

column1: 2. Forget trying to pass "real" business objects.  Instead
column2: just create simple DataTransfer objects which I will map back and forth to my real business objects manually.  They still get copied to new proxy objects by wsdl.exe anyway
column3: but at least I'm not tricking myself into thinking that web services can natively handle objects with business logic in them.

column1: By the way - Does anyone know how to tell wsdl.exe to *not* make a copy of the object?  Shouldn't we be able to just tell it
column2: "Hey
column3: use this existing type right over here. Don't copy it!"

column2: I've kinda settled on #2 for now
column3: but I'm curious what you all think.  I have a feeling there are *way* better ways to do this in general
column4: and I may not even be totally accurate on all my points
column5: so please let me know what your experiences have been.##C##<.net><webservices><soap><wsdl>##C##@$R$@

column1: 13348##C##367##C##5.43892383575439e-07##C##2753.13928159745##C##0##C##1419##C##0##C##9225##C##What are the advantages of using a single database for EACH client?##C##In a database-centric application that is designed for multiple clients
column2: I've always thought it was "better" to use a single database for ALL clients - associating records with proper indexes and keys.  In listening to the Stack Overflow podcast
column3: I heard Joel mention that FogBugz uses one database per client (so if there were 1000 clients
column4: there would be 1000 databases).  What are the advantages to using this architecture?

column1: I understand that for some projects clients need direct access to all of their data - in such an application
column2: it's obvious that each client needs their own database.  However
column3: for projects where a client does not need to access the database directly
column4: are there any advantages to using one database per client?  It seems that in terms of flexibility
column5: it's much simpler to use a single database with a single copy of the tables.  It's easier to add new features
column6: it's easier to create reports
column7: and it's just easier to manage.

column1: I was pretty confident in the "one database for all clients" method until I heard Joel (an experienced developer) mention that his software uses a different approach -- and I'm a little confused with his decision...
I've heard people cite that databases slow down with a large number of records
column2: but any relational database with some merit isn't going to have that problem - especially if proper indexes and keys are used.

column4: there is a public website where external users can submit and update information for various purposes. This information is then saved to a local SQL Server at the colo facility.

column2: approvals

column2: which is decent
column3: but obviously not the speediest thing in the world.

column2: and share many of the same tables
column3: but they are not 100% the same. Many of the tables on both sides are very specific to either the internal or external application.
