column2: how do you transfer that data to the internal application's database so it can be managed by the internal staff? And vice versa... how do you push updates made by the staff back out to the website?

column1: It is worth mentioning that the more "real time" these updates occur
column2: the better. Not that it has to be instant
column3: just reasonably quick.

column2: I have thought about using the following types of approaches:

column1: 2. Web service interfaces on both sides with code to sync the changes as they are made (in real time).

column10: it seemed that at some point it was not going to be as easy as initially I thought and as initially the product claims. This reminds me a very nice article called "[No Silver Bullet][2]".

column1: This CASE had its advantages but on the other hand it doesn't have resources you can consult and actually the license and certification are very expensive. For me another dissapointing thing is that because of its simplistic approach for development I felt scared on first hand cause of my unexperience on these kind of tools and second cause I thought that if I continued using it maybe it would have turned to be a complex monster that I could not manage later in the project.
I think its good to use these kind of solutions to speed up things but I wonder

column1: 13569##C##14226##C##14.9591442132369##C##2752.59209942119##C##0##C##501##C##0##C##96555##C##mysqli or PDO - what are the pros and cons?##C##In our place we're split between using mysqli and PDO for stuff like prepared statements and transaction support. Some projects use one

column2: I'm curious about the methodology behind creating standard libraries for interpreted languages. Specifically
column3: what seems to be the best approach? Defining standard functions/methods in the interpreted language
column4: or performing the processing of those calls in the compiled language in which the interpreter is written?

column1: What got me to thinking about this was the SO question about a stripslashes()-like function in Python. My first thought was "why not define your own and just call it when you need it"
column2: but it raised the question: is it preferable
column3: for such a function
column4: to let the interpreted language handle that overhead
column5: or would it be better to write an extension and leverage the compiled language behind the interpreter?##C##<language-agnostic><performance><language-features><interpreted>##C##@$R$@

13678##C##4985##C##0.0138649307191372##C##2752.34725046298##C##0##C##1730##C##0##C##6938##C##Textual versus Graphical Programming Languages##C##I am part of a high school robotics team
column2: and there is some debate about which language to use to program our robot.  We are choosing between C (or maybe C++) and LabVIEW.  There are pros for each language.

column1: - Good preparation for the future (most programming positions require text-based programmers.)
- We can expand upon our C codebase from last year
- Allows us to better understand what our robot is doing.
- Easier to visualize program flow (blocks and wires
column2: instead of lines of code)

column1: - "The future of programming is graphical."  (Think so?)
- Closer to the Robolab background that some new members may have.
- Don't need to intimately know what's going on.  Simply tell the module to find the red ball
column2: don't need to know how.

column1: This is a very difficult decision for us
column2: and we've been debating for a while.  Based on those pros for each language
column3: and on the experience you've got
column4: **what do you think the better option is?** Keep in mind that we aren't necessarily going for pure efficiency.  We also hope to prepare our programmers for a future in programming.

column1: - **Do you think that graphical languages such as LabVEIW are the future of programming?**
- **Is a graphical language easier to learn than a textual language?**  I think that they should be about equally challenging to learn.
-  Seeing as we are partailly rooted in helping people learn
column2: **how much should we rely on prewritten modules
column3: and how much should we try to write on our own?**  ("Good programmers write good code
column4: great programmers copy great code."  But isn't it worth being a good programmer
column5: first?)

column1: 14031##C##1525##C##0.00995825231075287##C##2751.99908329872##C##0##C##1165##C##0##C##4487##C##Database triggers##C##In the past I've never been a fan of using triggers on database tables. To me they always represented some "magic" that was going to happen on the database side
column2: far far away from the control of my application code. I also wanted to limit the amount of work the DB had to do
column3: as it's generally a shared resource and I always assumed triggers could get to be expensive in high load scenarios.

column2: I have found a couple of instances where triggers have made sense to use (at least in my opinion they made sense). Recently though
column3: I found myself in a situation where I sometimes might need to "bypass" the trigger. I felt really guilty about having to look for ways to do this
column4: and I still think that a better database design would alleviate the need for this bypassing. Unfortunately this DB is used by mulitple applications
column5: some of which are maintained by a very uncooperative development team who would scream about schema changes
column6: so I was stuck.

column1: What's the general consesus out there about triggers? Love em? Hate em? Think they serve a purpose in some scenarios?
Do think that having a need to bypass a trigger means that you're "doing it wrong"?##C##<sql-server><triggers><database-design>##C##@$R$@

column1: How would you go adding unit-testing to a game?
I believe you can unit test a lot of the game engine's functionality (networking
column2: object creation
column3: memory management
column4: etc)
column5: but is it possible to unit test the actual game itself?

column1: I'm not talking about gameplay elements (like Protoss would beat Zerg in map X)
column2: but I'm talking about the interaction between the game and the engine.

the engine is just a platform for the game. You could think of the game engine as an OS and the game as a software the OS would run. The game could be a collection of scripts or an actual subroutine inside the game engine.

column1: You would need an engine that is deterministic. This means that given one set of input
column2: the output would be exactly the same. This would inlude the random generator being seeded with the same input.
create a bare-bone level which contains a couple of objects the avatar/user can interact with. Start small and then add objects into the level as more interactions are developed.

column1: Create a script which follows a path (tests pathfinding) and interact with the different objects (store the result or expected behavior). This script would be your unit test. After a certain amount of time (say
column2: one week)
column3: run the script along with your engine's unit tests.

14596##C##30993##C##5.05379648134112##C##2751.43534082174##C##0##C##1320##C##1##C##351##C##Are there good resources on federated software?##C##Imagine you want to build a version of SOFlow that does *every* topic.  Much more encyclopædic -- somewhat similar to a collection of all of the "talk" pages on Wikipedia.  If I were designing this
column2: I wouldn't try to do it as one site.  I'd do it as a framework where anybody could create a version for their special topic
column3: but all of the special versions are aggregated.

column1: Do people know of sites that are managed this way?  How does the drill-down work?  How do you manage relationships between the many installations -- most of which aren't controlled (in any sense) by the body that manages the top level?

Simple links don't suffice for all aspects -- imagine trying to collect usage statistics and reputation numbers on one user from all the various installations.  How could you possibly generate the list of all the topics a person discusses when you don't even know what all the children sites are?  Is a shared meta-data registry a necessity?

column2: but distinct from [this question on distributed software][1].  Though "distributed" has many meanings
column3: one of the common themes is on inter-process communication.  This topic is important
column4: but not exactly what I'm thinking about here.

column1: 14674##C##144##C##5.08092298591509##C##2751.40266709495##C##0##C##1300##C##0##C##495##C##Different solutions/project files for Local vs Build environments##C##As part of improvements to our build process
column2: we are currently debating whether we should have separate project/solution files on our CI production environment from our local development environments.

column1: The reason this has come about is because of reference problems we experienced in our previous project.  On a frequent basis people would mistakenly add a reference to an assembly in the wrong location
column2: which would mean it would work okay on their local environment
column3: but might break on someone else's or on the build machine.

column2: the reference paths are in the csproj.user files which means these must be committed to source control
column3: so everyone has to share these same settings.

column1: So we are thinking about having separate projects and solutions on our CI server
column2: so that when we do a build it uses these projects rather than local development ones.

column1: It has obvious drawbacks such as an overhead to maintaining these separate files and the associated process that would need to be defined and followed
column2: but it has benefits in that we would be in more control over *EXACTLY* what happens in the production environment.

column1: What I haven't been able to find is anything on this subject - can't believe we are the only people to think about this - so all thoughts are welcome.

column2: I have recently turned on Common Language Runtime Support (/clr) on a large legacy project
column3: which uses MFC in a Shared DLL and relies on about a dozen other projects within our overall solution. This project is the core of our application
column4: and would drive any managed UI code that is produced (hence the need to turn on clr support for interop).

column1: After fixing a ton of little niggly errors and warnings
column2: I finally managed to get the application to compile..
running the application causes an EETypeLoadException and leaves me unable to debug...

I found the cause to be "System.TypeLoadException: Internal limitation: too many fields." which occurs right at the end of compilation. I then found [this link][1] which suggests to break the assembly down into two or more dlls. However
column3: this is not possible in my case
column4: as a limitation I have is that the legacy code basically remains untouched.

column1: Can anyone suggest any other possible solutions? I'm really at a dead end here.

column1: 14909##C##14835##C##11.2359741088003##C##2751.29291211814##C##0##C##951##C##0##C##269##C##Tree-Based (vs. HTML-Based) Web Framework?##C##Anyone who writes client-side JavaScript is familiar with the DOM - the tree structure that your browser references in memory
column2: generated from the HTML it got from the server. JavaScript can add
column3: remove and modify nodes on the DOM tree to make changes to the page. I find it very nice to work with (browser bugs aside)
column4: and very different from the way my server-side code has to generate the page in the first place.

column1: My question is: what server-side frameworks/languages build a page by treating it as a DOM tree from the beginning - inserting nodes instead of echoing strings? I think it would be very helpful if the client-side and server-side code both saw the page the same way. You could certainly hack something like this together in any web server language
column2: but a framework dedicated to creating a page this way could make some very nice optimizations.
being widely deployed and having been around a while would all be pluses.##C##<language>##C##@$R$@

column2: I've therefore been doing backups of the boxes by having a cron job upload tarballs containing the contents of /etc
column3: MySQL dumps and other such changing
column4: non-packaged data to a box at our geographically separate hosting centre.

column2: however that

column1: * the tarballs are sufficient to rebuild from
column2: but it's certainly not a painless process to do so (I recently tried this out as part of a hardware upgrade of one of the boxes)
the process isn't sustainable.  Each of the boxes is currently producing a tarball of a couple of hundred MB each day
column3: 99% of which is the same as the previous day

column1: * partly due to the size issue
column2: the backup process requires more manual intervention than I want (to find whatever 5GB file is inflating the size of the tarball and kill it)

column1: * again due to the size issue
column2: I'm leaving stuff out which it would be nice to include - the contents of users' home directories
column3: for example.  There's almost nothing of value there that isn't in source control (and these aren't our main dev boxes)
column4: but it would be nice to keep them anyway.

column1: * there must be a better way

column2: my question is
column3: how should I be doing this properly?  The requirements are:

column1: * needs to be an offsite backup (one of the main things I'm doing here is protecting against fire/whatever)
* should require as little manual intervention as possible (I'm lazy
column2: and box-herding isn't my main job)

column1: * should continue to scale with a couple more boxes
column2: slightly more data
column3: etc.

column1: * preferably free/open source (cost isn't the issue
column2: but especially for backups
column3: openness seems like a good thing)

column1: * an option to produce some kind of DVD/Blu-Ray/whatever backup from time to time wouldn't be bad
My first thought was that this kind of incremental backup was what tar was created for - create a tar file once each month
column2: add incrementally to it.  rsync results to remote box.  But others probably have better suggestions.

column2: note 12 in the standard seems to confirm that this is correct)
column3: but I don't see how you can allocate a buffer for the array to go in if this is the case.

column1: The following example shows the problem. Compiled with Visual Studio
column2: this example results in memory corruption:
char* argv[])
pA will be four bytes higher than pBuffer
Array address: %x\n"
column3: pBuffer
column4: pA);

column1: // Debug runtime will assert here due to heap corruption

column2: the compiler seems to be using the first four bytes of the buffer to store a count of the number of items in it. This means that because the buffer is only sizeof(A)*NUMELEMENTS big
column3: the last element in the array is written into unallocated heap.

column1: So the question is can you find out how much additional overhead your implementation wants in order to use placement new[] safely? Ideally
column2: I need a technique that's portable between different compilers. Note that
column3: at least in VC's case
column4: the overhead seems to differ for different classes. For instance
column5: if I remove the virtual destructor in the example
column6: the address returned from new[] is the same as the address I pass in.##C##<c++>##C##@$R$@

column1: 15310##C##9636##C##1.16359050897881##C##2751.06994533585##C##1##C##3658##C##0##C##11263##C##Optimizing the PDF Export of Huge Reports in Sql Reporting Services 2005##C##First off I understand that it is a horrible idea to run extremely large/long running reports. I am aware that Microsoft has a rule of thumb stating that a SSRS report should take no longer than 30 seconds to execute.  However sometimes gargantuan reports are a preferred evil due to external forces such complying with state laws.

column2: we have an asp.net (2.0) app that we have migrated from Crystal Reports to SSRS. Due to the large user base and complex reporting UI requirements we have a set of screens that accepts user inputted parameters and creates schedules to be run over night. Since the application supports multiple reporting frameworks we do not use the scheduling/snapshot facilities of SSRS. All of the reports in the system are generated by a scheduled console app which takes user entered parameters and generates the reports with the corresponding reporting solutions the reports were created with. In the case of SSRS reports
column3: the console app generates the SSRS reports and exports them as PDFs via the SSRS web service API.

column1: So far SSRS has been much easier to deal with than Crystal with the exception of a certain 25
column2: 000 page report that we have recently converted from crystal reports to SSRS. The SSRS server is a 64bit 2003 server with 32 gigs of ram running SSRS 2005. All of our smaller reports work fantastically
column3: but we are having trouble with our larger reports such as this one.  Unfortunately
column4: we can't seem to generate the aforemention report through the web service API. The following error occurs roughly 30-35 minutes into the generation/export:

column1: Exception Message: The underlying connection was closed: An unexpected error occurred on a receive.
The web service call is something I'm sure you all have seen before:

column2: this.ExportFormat
column3: null
column4: deviceInfo

column2: null
column3: null
column4: out encoding
column5: out mimeType
column6: out usedParameters

column2: out streamIds);

column1: The odd thing is that this report will run/render/export if the report is run directly on the reporting server using the report manager. The proc that produces the data for the report runs for about 5 minutes. The report renders in SSRS native format in the browser/viewer after about 12 minutes. Exporting to pdf through the browser/viewer in the report manager takes an additional 55 minutes. This works reliably and it produces a whopping 1.03gb pdf.
Here are some of the more obvious things I've tried to get the report working via the web service API:
value to 3 hours on the report
- disabled http keep alives on the report server
- increased the script timeout on the report server
- set the report to never time out on the server
- set the report timeout to several hours on the client call
From the tweaks I have tried
column2: I am fairly comfortable saying that any timeout issues have been eliminated.

column1: Based off of my research of the error message
column2: I believe that the web service API does not send chunked responses by default. This means that it tries to send all 1.3gb over the wire in one response. At a certain point
column3: IIS throws in the towel. Unfortunately the API abstracts away web service configuration so I can't seem to find a way to enable response chunking.

column1: 1. Does anyone know of anyway to reduce/optimize the PDF export phase and or the size of the PDF without lowering the total page count?
2. Is there a way to turn on response chunking for SSRS?
3. Does anyone else have any other theories as to why this runs on the server but not through the API?##C##<reporting-services><sqlreportingservices>##C##@$R$@

I have a table with a margin-bottom of 19px. Below that I have a form that contains some fieldsets. One of them is floated right. 2. Nixing the margin-bottom on the table and instead wrapping that with a div and giving it a padding-bottom of 19px. No apparent change.
3. Nixing the margin-bottom on the table and adding a div with a fixed height of 19px. No apparent change.
I know there are some others that I am forgetting
column2: but those are the things I have tried out recently. This happens to each fieldset.

column1: Scripts will be triggered upon certain events and may stay resident for a period of time. For example upon startup a script may define several options which the program presents to the user as a number of buttons. Upon selecting one of these buttons the program will notify the script where further events may occur.
These are the only real requirements;
1. Must be cross-platform and compilable from source
2. Scripts must be able to call registered code-side functions
3. Code must be able to call script-side functions
4. Be used within a C/C++ codebase.

15412##C##10100##C##10.7506705322303##C##2750.99235234968##C##0##C##932##C##1##C##3302##C##Is Single Responsibility Principle a rule of OOP?##C##An [answer][1] to a Stack Overflow question stated that a particular framework violated a plain and simple OOP rule: Single Responsibility Principle (SRP).
**Is the Single Responsibility Principle *really* a rule of OOP?**

My understanding of the definition of Object Orientated Programming is "a paradigm where objects and their behaviour are used to create software". This includes the following techniques: Encapsulation
column2: Polymorphism & Inheritance.

column1: Now don't get me wrong - I believe SRP to be the key to most good OO designs
column2: but I feel there are cases where this principle can and should be broken (just like database normalization rules). I aggressively push the benefits of SRP
column3: and the great majority of my code follows this principle.

column2: is it a rule
column3: and thus implies that it shouldn't be broken?*

column1: 15635##C##541##C##2.16439366340637e-06##C##2750.86382248858##C##0##C##1974##C##0##C##7782##C##Using Visual Studio to develop for C++ for Unix##C##Does anyone have battle stories to share trying to use Visual Studio to develop applications for Unix?  And I'm not talking using .NET with a Mono or Wine virtual platform running beneath.

Our company has about 20 developers all running Windows XP/Vista and developing primarily for Linux & Solaris.  Until recently we all logged into a main Linux server and modified/built code the good old fashioned way: Emacs
column2: Vi
column3: dtpad - take your pick.  Then someone said
column4: "hey - we're living in the Dark Ages
column5: we should be using an IDE".

column1: So we tried out a few and decided that Visual Studio was the only one that would meet our performance needs (yes
column2: I'm sure that IDE X is a very nice IDE
column3: but we chose VS).

column2: how do you setup your environment to have the files available locally to VS
column3: but also available to a build server?  We settled with writing a Visual Studio plugin - it writes our files locally and to the build server whenever we hit "Save" and we have a bit fat "sync" button that we can push when our files change on the server side (for when we update to the latest files from our source control server).

column1: The plugin also uses Visual Studio's external build system feature that ultimately just ssh's into the build server and calls our local "make" utility (which is Boost Build v2 - has great dependency checking
column2: but is *really* slow to start as a result i.e. 30-60 seconds to begin).  The results are piped back into Visual Studio so the developer can click on the error and be taken to the appropriate line of code (quite slick actually).  The build server uses GCC and cross-compiles all of our Solaris builds.

column1: But even after we've done all this
column2: I can't help but sigh whenever I start to write code in Visual Studio.  I click a file
column3: start typing
column4: and VS chugs to catch up with me.

column1: Is there anything more annoying than having to stop and wait for your tools?  Are the benefits worth the frustration?

column2: stories
column3: help?

column1: 15768##C##16287##C##1.36005050921813##C##2750.75987850688##C##0##C##1111##C##1##C##5237##C##Measuring Developer Performance##C##Every day after I finish a hard days coding (or an easy days youtubing) I log work done against the tickets I have been (obstentibly) working on. Then Mr. Manager takes this oh-so-useful information and builds a [burn-down chart][1]. This then allows us to track how 'complete' we are in the overall scope of things. It also allows us to measure our velocity (essentially How Fast We Get Things Done).

I've noticed that some people complete their tasks well under the original estimate (which makes us look good) and some people complete their tasks over the original estimate (which makes us look bad).
While this measures how quickly people finish tasks it doesn't measure how well. It really gives you no solid indication of developer performance.
Neither does lines of code (you don't want devs to be overly verbose).
Neither does bugs raised (you are now basing the performance of a developer on the performance of a tester; they could not raise enough or raise too many).
So how would you go about measuring developer performance?

15805##C##1391##C##1.88346489565447##C##2750.72484618053##C##0##C##1341##C##0##C##599##C##Why are my auto-run applications acting weird on Vista?##C##The product we are working on allows the user to easily set it up to run automatically whenever the computer is started. This is helpful because the product is part of the basic work environment of most of our users.
This feature was implemented not so long ago and for a while all was well
column2: but when we started testing this feature on Vista the product started behaving really weird on startup. Specifically
column3: our product makes use of another product (lets call it X) that it launches whenever it needs its services. The actual problem is that whenever X is launched immediately after log-on
column4: it crashes or reports critical errors related to disk access (this happens even when X is launched directly - not through our product).

column1: This happens whenever we run our product by registering it in the "Run" key in the registry or place a shortcut to it in the "Startup" folder inside the "Start Menu"
column2: even when we put a delay of ~20 seconds before actually starting to run. When we changed the delay to 70 seconds
column3: all is well.

column1: We tried to reproduce the problem by launching our product manually immediately after logon (by double-clicking on a shortcut placed on the desktop) but to no avail.
Now how is it possible that applications that run normally a minute after logon report such hard errors when starting immediately after logon?##C##<windows-vista>##C##@$R$@

**Is there a way in PHP to overwrite a method declared by one interface in an interface extending that interface?**

column2: but here is what I have:
$shipment = null);
when you extend something
column3: you can overwrite any method contained therein (right?). However
column4: when one interface extends another
column5: it won't let you. Unless I'm thinking about this wrong... When I implement the iShipper interface
column6: I don't have to make the Shipper object extend the Vendor object (that implements the iVendor interface). I just say:

column1: and make FedEx implement all of the methods from iVendor and iShipper. However
column2: I need the __construct functions in iVendor and iShipper to be unique. I know I could take out the $shipment = null
column3: but then it wouldn't be as convenient to create Shippers (by just passing in the vendors_no and the shipment while instantiating).

column1: Anyone know how to make this work? My fallback is to have to set the shipment by calling $shipper->setShipment($shipment); on the Shipper after I instantiate it
column2: but I'm hoping for a way to get around having to do that...

column1: *A little more explanation for the curious:*
*The FedEx Object has methods that go to the FedEx site (using cURL) and gets an estimate for the Shipment in question. I have a UPS Object
column2: a BAXGlobal Object
column3: a Conway Object
column4: etc. Each one has COMPLETELY different methods for actually getting the shipping estimate
column5: but all the system needs to know is that they are a "shipper" and that the methods listed in the interface are callable on them (so it can treat them all exactly the same
column6: and loop through them in a "shippers" array calling getTransitX() to find the best shipper for a shipment).*

column2: and is treated as such in other parts of the system (getting and putting in the DB
column3: etc. Our data design is a pile of crap
column4: so FedEx is stored right alongside companies like Dunder Mifflin in the "Vendors" table
column5: which means it gets to have all the properties of every other Vendor
column6: but needs the extra properties and methods supplied by iShipper).*##C##<php><oop><interface><extends>##C##@$R$@

One of the things I've asked a lot about on this site is [LINQ][1]. The questions I've asked have been wide and varied and often don't have much context behind them. So in an attempt to consolidate the knowledge I've acquired on Linq I'm posting this question with a view to maintaining and updating it with additional information as I continue to learn about LINQ.
I also hope that it will prove to be a useful resource for other people wanting to learn about LINQ.
> The LINQ Project is a codename for a

column2: set
column3: and

column1: > and Visual Basic with native language
> syntax for queries and provides class
> libraries to take advantage of these
What this means is that LINQ provides a standard way to query a variety of datasources using a common syntax.
## What flavours of LINQ are there?
Currently there are a few different LINQ providers:
[Linq to Objects][3] which allows you to execute queries on any IEnumerable object.
[Linq to SQL][4] which allows you to execute queries against a database in an object oriented manner.
[Linq to XML][5] which allows you to query
column2: load
column3: validate
column4: serialize and manipulate XML documents.

column1: - Standardized way to query multiple datasources
- Optimized way to perform set based operations on in memory objects
##So what can I do with LINQ?
[Chook][6] provides a way to [output CSV files][7]
[Jeff][8] shows how to [remove duplicates from an array][9]
Bob gets a [distinct ordered list from a datatable][10]

Scott Guthrie provides an [intro to Linq on his blog][14]

column2: you might see this exception when you try to execute a query:

column1: A transport-level error has occurred when sending the request to the server.

column2: this is something that "just happens" and not much can be done to prevent it.  It does not happen as a result of a bad query
column3: and generally cannot be duplicated.  It just crops up maybe once every few days in a busy OLTP system when the TCP connection to the database goes bad for some reason.

column1: 16969##C##7670##C##0.0816419329494238##C##2750.11554313637##C##0##C##2074##C##1##C##1551##C##.net solution subversion best practices?##C##There are so many examples of how to set up your dotnet projects but none seemed to fit our situation.
We have one solution with multiple applications
column2: multiple dependencies.  We're on SourceSafe currently and are planning to move to subversion but are finding it difficult to organize our source the right way.

column1: We also have a configuration management system which deploys (via copy from database) depending on which workload the operator is working.  We mark an application "release" with a version and to that release we add multiple file dependencies.  Bear in mind the solution we have in place now is an attempt to band-aid the old (windows 3.1 developed) solution to work with .NET file/dependency structure.
In the case of App1 we have App1.exe
column2: BizObjects.dll
column3: DataAccess.dll
column4: and CustomControls.dll.

column1: We have the same set of dependencies for App2 due to BizObjects referencing DataAccess -- but this is defined manually.  We don't have a system in place to identify the dependency tree.
Each of the dependencies for a "release" is a file and version id.  And the same application could contain different versions for each file for a different workload.
1. Where in the world have we gone wrong? Did we go wrong?
2. How can we structure a svn source tree to accommodate the deployment requirements?
3. how can we re-structure the code the better support a deployment strategy which makes sense for our setup?
We have an old and over-engineered solution to (it would seem) a relatively simple problem.  Can anyone steer me/us in the right direction?

edit: I read this(http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3667/what-is-your-favorite-web-app-deployment-workflow-with-svn) question and remembered we also have the same dev/test/prod areas which the code must move through.

further into my adventures with custom controls...
here is that I have learned of three main "classes" of custom controls. Please feel free to correct me if any of this is wrong!

column1: 1. **UserControls** - Which inherit from _UserControl_ and are contained within an _ASCX_ file. These are pretty limited in what they can do
column2: but are a quick and light way to get some UI commonality with designer support.

column1: 2. **Custom Composite Controls** - These are controls that inherit from _WebControl_ where you add pre-existing controls to the control within the _CreateChildControls_ method. This provides great flexibility
column2: but lack of designer support without additional coding. They are highly portable though since they can be compiled into a DLL.

column1: 3. **Custom Rendered Controls** - Similar to Custom Composite Controls
column2: these are added to a Web Control Library project. The rendering of the control is completely controlled by the programmer by overriding the _Render_ method.
so while playing with custom composites
column3: I found the following:

column1: * You have little/no control over the HTML output making it difficult to "debug".
* The _CreateChildControls_ (and subsequent methods) can get real busy with _Controls.Add(myControl)_ everywhere.
* I found rendering tables (be it for layout or content) to be considerably awkward.

column2: I admit
column3: I am new to this so I could be way off-base with some of my points noted above..

column1: * Do you have any neat tricks to control the HTML output?
* Do you just say "to hell with it" and go ahead and create a custom rendered control?
**Its something I am keen to get really firm in my mind since I know how much _good_ control development can cut overall development time.**
I look forward to your answers ^_^##C##<c#><.net><asp.net><controls><user-controls>##C##@$R$@

column1: 17670##C##603##C##14.9815298495814##C##2749.59927543998##C##0##C##1108##C##1##C##616##C##Suitable alternative to CryptEncrypt##C##We have a situation in our product where for a long time some data has been stored in the application's database as SQL string (choice of MS SQL server or sybase SQL anywhere) which was encrypted via the Windows API function [CryptEncrypt.][1]  (direct and decryptable)
The problem is that CryptEncrypt can produce NULL's in the output
column2: meaning that when it's stored in the database
column3: the string manipulations will at some point truncate the ciphertext.

column1: Ideally we'd like to use an algo that will produce cyphertext that doesn't contain NULLs as that will cause the least amount of change to the existing databases (changing a column from string to binary and code to deal with binary instead of strings) and just decrypt existing data and re-encrypt with the new algo at database upgrade time.
The algorithm doesn't need to be the most secure
column2: as the database is already in a reasonably secure environment (not an open network / teh interwebs) but does need to bebetter than ROT13 (which I can almost decrypt in my head now!)

column2: Complex Objects as a Web Service Result##C##Hello again ladies and gents!
following on from my other question on [ASP.NET Web Service Results
column3: Proxy Classes and Type Conversion](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6681/aspnet-web-service-results-proxy-classes-and-type-conversion). I've come to a part in my project where I need to get my thinking cap on.

column2: we have a large
column3: complex custom object that needs to be returned from a Web Service and consumed in the client application.

column2: based on the previous discussion
column3: we know this is going to then take the form of the proxy class(es) as the return type. To overcome this
column4: we need to basically copy the properties from one to the other.

column2: that is something that I would really
column3: really
column4: _really!_ like to avoid!

column2: it got me thinking
column3: **how else could we do this?**

column1: My current thoughts are to enable the object for complete serialization to XML and then return the XML as a string from the Web Service. We then de-serialize at the client. This will mean a fair bit of attribute decorating
column2: but at least the code at both endpoints will be light
column3: namely by just using the .NET XML Serializer.

column1: 17732##C##8506##C##9.25734639167786e-07##C##2749.5407490395##C##0##C##1251##C##2##C##22920##C##When should assertions stay in production code?##C##There's a [discussion][1] going on over at comp.lang.c++.moderated about whether or not assertions
column2: which in C++ only exist in debug builds by default
column3: should be kept in production code or not.

column2: each project is unique
column3: so my question here is **not** so much **whether** assertions should be kept
column4: **but in which cases** this is recommendable/not a good idea.

column2: I mean:

column1: - A run-time check that tests a condition which
column2: when false
column3: reveals a bug in the software.

column1: - A mechanism by which the program is halted (maybe after really minimal clean-up work).
I'm not necessarily talking about C or C++.
My own opinion is that if you're the programmer
column2: but don't own the data (which is the case with most commercial desktop applications)
column3: you should keep them on
column4: because a failing asssertion shows a bug
column5: and you should not go on with a bug
column6: with the risk of corrupting the user's data. This forces you to test strongly before you ship
column7: and makes bugs more visible
column8: thus easier to spot and fix.

column1: [1]: http://groups.google.com/group/comp.lang.c++.moderated/browse_thread/thread/8e0235d58c8635c2 "assertions: does it matter that they are disabled in production?"##C##<quality><assert>##C##@$R$@

18642##C##4902##C##0.230939779896289##C##2749.18682928244##C##0##C##478##C##2##C##16285##C##What is the most unreadable programming language?##C##Excluding [Whitespace][1] and assembly
column2: what do you think is the most difficult programming language to write readable code in?

column1: I find that I'm very comfortable reading code with C/C++ style braces and brackets.  I can easily scan a file for method and class definitions
column2: however in a language which does not use braces I find it extremely hard to read
column3: eg: BASIC variants
column4: specifically Visual Basic.

column2: I realize I might be downvoted into oblivion for this question
column3: especially given my stance on the matter
column4: but I really need to see some honest
column5: thoughtful debate on the merits of the currently accepted enterprise application design paradigm.

column1: I am not convinced that entity objects should exist.
By entity objects I mean the typical things we tend to build for our applications
column2: like "Person"
column3: "Account"
column4: "Order"
column5: etc.

column1: My current design philosophy is this:
- All database access must be accomplished via stored procedures.

column2: call a stored procedure and iterate over a SqlDataReader or the rows in a DataTable

column1: (Note: I have also built enterprise applications with J2EE
column2: java folks please substitute the equvalent for my .NET examples)

column1: I am not anti-OO.  I write lots of classes for different purposes
column2: just not entities.  I will admit that a large portion of the classes I write are static helper classes.

column1: I am not building toys.  I'm talking about large
column2: high volume transactional applications deployed across multiple machines.  Web applications
column3: windows services
column4: web services
column5: b2b interaction
column6: you name it.

column1: I have used OR Mappers.  I have written a few.  I have used the J2EE stack
column2: CSLA
column3: and a few other equivalents.  I have not only used them but actively developed and maintained these applications in production environments.

column1: I have come to the battle-tested conclusion that entity objects are getting in our way
column2: and our lives would be *so* much easier without them.

column1: Consider this simple example: you get a support call about a certain page in your application that is not working correctly
column2: maybe one of the fields is not being persisted like it should be.  With my model
column3: the developer assigned to find the problem opens *exactly 3 files*.  An ASPX
column4: an ASPX.CS and a SQL file with the stored procedure.  The problem
column5: which might be a missing parameter to the stored procedure call
column6: takes minutes to solve.  But with any entity model
column7: you will invariably fire up the debugger
column9: and you may end up with 15-20 files open in Visual Studio.  By the time you step down to the bottom of the stack
column10: you forgot where you started.  We can only keep so many things in our heads at one time.  Software is incredibly complex without adding any unnecessary layers.

column1: Development complexity and troubleshooting are just one side of my gripe.
Do developers realize that each and every time they write or modify any code that interacts with the database
column2: they need to do a throrough analysis of the exact impact on the database?  And not just the development copy
column3: I mean a mimic of production
column4: so you can see that the additional column you now require for your object just invalidated the current query plan and a report that was running in 1 second will now take 2 minutes
column5: just because you added a single column to the select list?  And it turns out that the index you now require is so big that the DBA is going to have to modify the physical layout of your files?

column1: If you let people get too far away from the physical data store with an abstraction
column2: they will create havoc with an application that needs to scale.

column1: I am not a zealot.  I can be convinced if I am wrong
column2: and maybe I am
column3: since there is such a strong push towards Linq to Sql
column4: ADO.NET EF
column5: Hibernate
column6: J2EE
column7: etc.  Please think through your responses
column8: if I am missing something I really want to know what it is
column9: and why I should change my thinking.##C##<sql><database><orm><entities>##C##@$R$@

column1: 18959##C##28##C##7.2922557592392e-07##C##2749.07903796295##C##0##C##2244##C##0##C##3426##C##How to match linux device path to windows drive name?##C##I'm writing an application that on some stage performs low-level disk operations in Linux environment. The app actually consists of 2 parts
column2: one runs on Windows and interacts with a user and another is a linux part that runs from a LiveCD. User makes a choice of Windows drive letters and then a linux part performs actions with corresponding partitions. The problem is finding a match between a Windows drive letter (like C:) and a linux device name (like /dev/sda1). This is my current solution that I rate as ugly:
number of blocks
column3: drive serial number etc.) in Windows in some pre-defined place (i.e. the root of the system partition).

column1: - read a list of partitions from /proc/partitions. Get only those partitions that has major number for SCSI or IDE hard drives and minor number that identifies them as real partitions and not the whole disks.
- Try to mount each of them with either ntfs or vfat file systems. Check whether the mounted partition contains the information stored by Windows app.
- Upon finding the required information written by the Windows app make the actual match. For each partition found in /proc/partitions acquire drive serial number (via HDIO_GET_IDENTITY syscall)
column2: number of blocks (from /proc/partitions) and drive offset (/sys/blocks/drive_path/partition_name/start)
column3: compare this to the Windows information and if this matches - store a Windows drive letter along with a linux device name.

column1: There are a couple of problems in this scheme:
- This is ugly. Writing data in Windows and then reading it in Linux makes testing a nightmare.
- linux device major number is compared only with IDE or SCSI devices. This would probably fail
column2: i.e. on USB or FireWire disks. It's possible to add these types of disks
column3: but limiting the app to only known subset of possible devices seems to be rather bad idea.

column1: - looks like HDIO_GET_IDENTITY works only on IDE and SATA drives.
- /sys/block hack may not work on other than IDE or SATA drives.
Any ideas on how to improve this schema? Perhaps there is another way to determine windows names without writing all the data in windows app?
P.S. The language of the app is C++. I can't change this.##C##<c++><linux><drive>##C##@$R$@

19164##C##41532##C##7.60102508077398##C##2748.96709930571##C##0##C##2035##C##0##C##4710##C##Do You Really Know Your Programming Languages?##C##I am often amazed at how little some of my colleagues know or care about their craft. Something that constantly frustrates me is that people don't want to learn any more than they need to about the programming languages they use every day.
Many programmers seem content to learn some pidgin sub-dialect
column2: and stick with that. If they see a keyword or construct that they aren't familiar with
column3: they'll complain that the code is "tricky."

column1: What would you think of a civil engineer who shied away from calculus because it had "all those tricky math symbols?"
I'm not suggesting that we all need to become "language lawyers." But if you make your living as a programmer
column2: and claim to be a competent user of language X
column3: then I think at a minimum you should know the following:

column1: - What are all the keywords of the language?
- What are all the valid syntactic forms?

column2: files
column3: and other operating system resources managed?

column1: - Where is the official language specification and library reference for the language?

The last one is the one that really gets me. Many programmers seem to have no idea that there is a "specification" or "standard" for any particular language. I still talk to people who think that Microsoft invented C++
column2: and that if a program doesn't compile under VC6
column3: it's not a valid C++ program.

column1: Programmers these days have it easy when it comes to obtaining specs. Newer languages like C#
column2: Java
column3: Python
column4: Ruby
column5: etc. all have their documentation available for free from the vendors' web sites. Older languages and platforms often have standards controlled by standards bodies that demand payment for specs
column6: but even that shouldn't be a deterrent: the C++ standard is available from ISO for $30 (and why am I the only person I know who has a copy?).

column1: Programming is hard enough even when you do know the language. If you don't
column2: I don't see how you have a chance.

column1: What do the rest of you think?  Am I right
column2: or should we all be content with the typical level of programming language expertise?##C##<language-features><language-agnostic><rant>##C##@$R$@

19481##C##144##C##7.83482465241104##C##2748.64876542846##C##0##C##1122##C##0##C##3365##C##Data binding is a bad idea?##C##Another discussion (we've been having a lot of them these days!) in our work is whether data binding is a bad idea or not.

column2: I think it is A BAD THING.

column1: 1) It circumvents my well architectured MVP framework - with databinding
column2: the view communicates bi-directionally with a model.  Ewww.

column1: 2) It promotes hooking up view controls to datafields at design time.  In my experience
column2: this leads to vital code (binding column A to Field X) being obscure and hidden away in some designer file.  IMO this code should be explicit and in-your-face
column3: so that it is easy to modify and see what is going on
column4: without having to use a clunky designer interface.

column1: 3) Relating to Point 1) this direct binding makes it harder to isolate each component (view
column2: model
column3: controller/presenter) and unit-test.

column1: The PROS are that it is easy to set up
column2: and you can take advantage of some nice features (validation etc) which come with the plumbing already done for you.
databinding becomes much more of a hindrance when dealing with a large data-centric application.

column1: 19952##C##710##C##15.2058618864976##C##2748.4231944792##C##0##C##1451##C##1##C##748##C##RFC calculation in Java need help with algorithm##C##The RFC for a Java class is set of all methods that can be invoked in response to a message to an object of the class or by some method in the class.
M = Number of methods in the class.
R = Total number of other methods directly invoked from the M.
Thinking C is the .class and J is the .java file of which we need to calculate RFC.
and R=9  (Dont worry about call inside a loop. Its considered as a single call)
Calculating M is easy. Load C using classloader and use reflection to get the count of methods.
Calculating R is not direct. We need to count the number of method calls from the class. First level only.
For calculating R i must use regex. Usually format would be ( calls with out using. are not counted)
with out semicolon when call return is directly becomes parameter to another method.
What other pattern of method call can u think of?  Is there any other way other than using RegEx that can be used to calculate R.##C##<java><regex><algorithm><reflection><regularexpression>##C##@$R$@

20003##C##1663##C##13.7782466434874##C##2748.41198090278##C##0##C##1312##C##0##C##3529##C##Repository layout for large Maven projects##C##I have a large application (~50 modules) using a structure similar to the following:

One is using a tree structure just as the previous one. The drawback of this structure is that you need a ton of tweaking/hacks to get the multi-module reporting work well with Maven. Another downside is that in Subversion the standard trunk/tags/branches approach add even more complexity to the repository.

column1: 20034##C##7256##C##5.82426724536344##C##2748.40750778932##C##0##C##2239##C##2##C##4352##C##Is Project Darkstar Realistic?##C##[Project Darkstar][1] was the topic of the monthly [JavaSIG][2] meeting down at the Google offices in NYC last night.  For those that don't know (probably everyone)
column2: Project Darkstar is a framework for massively multiplayer online games that attempts to take care of all of the "hard stuff."  The basic idea is that you write your game server logic in such a way that all operations are broken up into tiny tasks.  You pass these tasks to the Project Darkstar framework which handles distributing them to a specific node in the cluster
column3: any concurrency issues
column4: and finally persisting the data.

column1: Apparently doing this kind of thing is a much different problem for video games than it is for enterprise applications.  Jim Waldo
column2: who gave the lecture
column3: claims that MMO games have a DB read/write ration of 50/50
column4: whereas enterprise apps are more like 90% read
column5: 10% write.  He also claims that most existing MMOs keep everything in memory exlcusively
column6: and only dump to a DB every 6 hours of so.  This means if a server goes down
column7: you would lose all of the work since the last DB dump.

column2: the project itself sounds really cool
column3: but I don't think the industry will accept it.  First
column4: you have to write your server code in Java.  The client code can be written in anything (Jim claims ActionScript 3 is the most popular
column5: follow by C++)
column6: but the server stuff has to be Java.  Sounds good to me
column7: but I really get the impression that everyone in the games industry hates Java.

column2: unlike other industries where developers prefer to use existing frameworks and libraries
column3: the guys in the games industry seem to like to write everything themselves.  Not only that
column4: they like to rewrite everything for every new game they produce.  Things are starting to change where developers are using Havok for physics
column5: Unreal Engine 3 as their platform
column6: etc.
column7: but for the most part it looks like everything is still proprietary.

column2: are the guys at Project Darkstar just wasting their time?  Can a general framework like this really work for complex games with the performance that is required?  Even if it does work
column3: are game companies willing to use it?

20047##C##36925##C##20.9973420486785##C##2748.40368472226##C##1##C##2726##C##2##C##25834##C##Diagnosing Deadlocks in SQL Server 2005##C##We're seeing some pernicious
column2: but rare
column3: deadlock conditions in the Stack Overflow SQL Server 2005 database.

column2: set up a trace profile using [this excellent article on troubleshooting deadlocks](http://www.simple-talk.com/sql/learn-sql-server/how-to-track-down-deadlocks-using-sql-server-2005-profiler/)
column3: and captured a bunch of examples. The weird thing is that **the deadlocking write is *always* the same**:

column2: [LastActivityDate] = @p2
column3: [LastActivityUserId] = @p3

column2: but it's usually some kind of trivial
column3: simple **read** of the posts table. This one always gets killed in the deadlock. To be perfectly clear
column4: we are not seeing write / write deadlocks
column5: but read / write.

column1: We have a mixture of LINQ and parameterized SQL queries at the moment. We have added `with (nolock)` to all the SQL queries. This may have helped some. We also had a single (very) poorly-written badge query that I fixed yesterday
column2: which was taking upwards of 20 seconds to run every time
column3: and was running every minute on top of that. I was hoping this was the source of some of the locking problems!

column2: I got another deadlock error about 2 hours ago. Same exact symptoms
column3: same exact culprit write.

column1: The truly strange thing is that the locking write SQL statement you see above is part of a very specific code path. It's *only* executed when a new answer is added to a question -- it updates the parent question with the new answer count and last date/user. This is
column2: obviously
column3: not that common relative to the massive number of reads we are doing! As far as I can tell
column4: we're not doing huge numbers of writes anywhere in the app.

column1: I realize that NOLOCK is sort of a giant hammer
column2: but most of the queries we run here don't need to be that accurate. Will you care if your user profile is a few seconds out of date?

column1: Using NOLOCK with Linq is a bit more difficult as [Scott Hanselman discusses here](http://www.hanselman.com/blog/GettingLINQToSQLAndLINQToEntitiesToUseNOLOCK.aspx).
We are flirting with the idea of using
SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ UNCOMMITTED
on the base database context so that all our LINQ queries have this set. Without that
column2: we'd have to wrap every LINQ call we make (well
column3: the simple reading ones
column4: which is the vast majority of them) in a 3-4 line transaction code block
column5: which is ugly.

column1: I guess I'm a little frustrated that trivial reads in SQL 2005 can deadlock on writes. I could see write/write deadlocks being a huge issue
column2: but *reads?* We're not running a banking site here
column3: we don't need perfect accuracy every time.

20084##C##18104##C##12.3189025921747##C##2748.39521415532##C##1##C##1356##C##2##C##42097##C##XML Serialization and Inherited Types##C##following on from my [previous question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19454/enforce-attribute-decoration-of-classesmethods) I have been working on getting my object model to serialize to XML. But I have now run into a problem (quelle surprise!).
The problem I have is that I have a collection
column2: which is of a abstract base class type
column3: which is populated by the concrete derived types.

column1: I thought it would be fine to just add the XML attributes to all of the classes involved and everything would be peachy. Sadly
column2: thats not the case!

column1: So I have done some digging on Google and I now understand _why_ it's not working.. In that **the _XmlSerializer_ is in fact doing some clever reflection in order to serialize objects to/from XML
column2: and since its based on the abstract type
column3: it cannot figure out what the hell it's talking to**. Fine.

column1: I did come across [this page](http://www.codeproject.com/KB/XML/xmlserializerforunknown.aspx) on CodeProject
column2: which looks like it may well help a lot (yet to read/consume fully)
column3: but I thought I would like to bring this problem to the StackOverflow table too
column4: to see if you have any neat hacks/tricks in order to get this up and running in the quickest/lightest way possible :)

column1: There seems to be a lot of  "Animal/Mammal"
column2: "Car/Bike/Truck" examples but not a lot of fresh ideas!
